dialogue.text: Can I help you sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes you can help me.  Where is my luggage?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, let me just check on that for you.  Where are you coming--?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  You do that.  I'm coming from Baltimore.  You know where that is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, yes it's in Maryland.  It's okay...well, I'm...just let me check here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I had eight hundred pounds of luggage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Sir?  Can you...if you just give me one moment and let me just check okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Check.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright.  And you're coming-- Wait, hold on sir.  You're coming from Baltimore into LAX right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it there?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay and this is direct flight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know where we're at?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm asking you if this is direct flight from Baltimore to LAX or if you have to stop--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I've been waiting here for four hours for my luggage

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and it's not here, they told me to go to this person, go to this person.  Now I'm at this person.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're at me and I'm going to try to help you out sir but you just have to cooperate with me--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many pieces of luggage do you have checked in?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Eight.  And they're all gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Eight pieces of luggage.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what are you going to do about it?  You going to call someone?  You going to send me somewhere else?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm just going to check--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's my mother's funeral tomorrow and the urn is in the suitcase.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm very sorry but let's check on this immediately.  This is definitely an emergency.  It seems--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I going to do tomorrow without the urn?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir it seems to me that your luggage is um- is not here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, that's a good deduction.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes--it is

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sherlock Holmes.  God, where's my luggage?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, Please please, I would ask you to just calm down for a second--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm down?  It's my mother's funeral tomorrow.  I'm the one responsible for this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  We will find your luggage.  Apparently because it somehow...what flight you were taking, you were on Delta?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  You are a Delta representative.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What is the matter with you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, I just...you need to calm down is what needs to happen right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't yell at me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm not.  I'm sorry, I am being--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: calm.  Sir, okay basically what- what's going to happen here is you're going to give me your contact information and we will contact you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God.  I think a blood vessel burst in my head.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Please, please

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: sir, listen to me.  Your luggage is still in Baltimore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  We can get it here in about seven to ten business days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  Well, because--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give- Give me your manager right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am the manager sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're the manager? You don't know where you work for, you don't know where you're at and you're the manager?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir I know where I work for but I was checking because you cannot--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whose daughter are you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sir. Sir. Sir. Sir

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is your name?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My name is Brent Caption.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now what are you going to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's it going, babe?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey listen,eh- I've been wanting to talk to you. I have something to tell you. How's Amy doing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's doing fine. She just took her first steps today actually. I videotaped it for you so you can watch it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I really want to say that. Well I, so, you know, at the center department they called me in and I talked to-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah? What did they say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well umm- actually they--I was promoted.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, wow. That's great.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And Uh- Yeah. Uh- They're going to need um- more nurses on call for uh- to go overseas to help out with the war.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And uh - seeing as I was uh- promoted and head of the department now, and so- well, they asked me to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: when?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going- It's going to be probably in about three weeks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? You can't do that. Three weeks?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm leaving in three weeks, but-- Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, we're supposed to take a look at a house next week.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we can still do that

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't- No, I can't do this alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and uh--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amy's starting school in a month.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, but look, I have to take this. I mean, if I don't, I mean, I could get fired.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And we know you need-we need the money. We couldn't even- purchase a house if I didn't take this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what happened to my cousin. She went and she never came back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey, I'm going to come back. It's not like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But it- it is for a year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Babe, I'm sorry. But I don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know as much as -as much as me that I-I want to stay here with you and Amy so bad, but I can't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember the last time you went? You know how hard it was for me? Now we have a kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But you're so good with her. You know, she knows you better than she knows me 'cause I'm at work every day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Babe, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't leave your daughter alone like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But she has you. I mean, that's what you're there for. You're my right-hand man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't postpone it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Wait, you can write me and as you know, send me pictures.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if I can handle you going another year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if I- if I could take it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I need you to be strong for me. 'Cause I can't be the only one that's strong right now, really, I--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't be that strong. A whole year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: me, oh my god.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But we can work, you know, we--you can write me and we could see pictures

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What if you don't come back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and if we survive, if we survive that then babe, you know you know we could survive any--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will come back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I supposed--oh, one out of five people aren't coming back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It doesn't look very good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can do it. I'm going to do it. And I'll be back safe and sound and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: we'll have all the money that we ever needed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And- And then I'll stop working and- I'll stay home with the baby.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want the money. I want-you here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: we'll get money, all right? You don't need the job, all right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If your life is going to be in danger and this family is going to be in danger we don't need the job. We'll find the money.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's all I ever knew how to do. I can't quit now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How are we supposed to tell Amy? How's she supposed to understand that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, we- we tell her mommy's going on va- on a trip for for- a while.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How is she going to feel the first year in school, no mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't do that to me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's hard enough already, Brian, I can't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not thinking about just me; I'm thinking about our child.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't expect this to happen. I never planned for this. Some things you just don't plan for, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, babe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look sir, I've been waiting for about an hour and my luggage still hasn't come. What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Rosenkrantz, but uh- I don't know what to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, you don't know what to tell me? I have two luggage that I've been coming--they're coming--from France and I need them here. I'm home now. I need to go start working.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you- Did you check with the lost and found?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where? I don't know. The lost and found. What do you mean, lost and found?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I had my luggage transferred here from Paris to L.A. and now I'm here and I need to be working and I have all my stuff in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe it got lost. Did you think about that, mom?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's what I'm asking you. What--I don't know what happened to it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, not--we didn't lose it; maybe the airport lost it. Maybe someone stole it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Wait, sir. You're- You're completely not--what do you mean, stole it? How can they just steal it from an airplane? It was up in the air?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I mean, maybe in the little--going around thingy thing where bopper stole it from there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. All I know is that I am supposed to have my language here right now. Right now. And it's not there. And you're supposed to help me because you work at the airport. So give me my luggage or tell me where the hell it is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. What can we do is we can get your name and information and if it shows up we can send it to you so-- Wherever you stay

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, if it shows up? No, I need it now. I have my keys, I have my wallet, I have my money. I have thousands and thousands of dollars worth of stuff in there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not to mention I have my work in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'll have you fill out some paperwork and see if you can get started on something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what if- what if it is lost? Well, what are you guys going to do for me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, we'll file a complaint and we could possibly, you know, replace some of the things. I think-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and when you sign your ticket we could replace about fifteen percent of what's in the bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fifteen percent?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Up to a limit of twenty five dollars.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What? There- There's hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stuff in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whoa, maybe you should uh- have thought of a better way to send it than just in a bag, hmm? Did you think about that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no. You don't understand. This is--these are my belongings in the luggage. And I went to Paris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, why are you laughing at me? This isn't funny.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think that's kind of stupid, that you put a hundred thousands of dollars in the bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm sorry, if I--no, it's not stupid. You are supposed to have my luggage.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you lock- Did you lock it even? You probably didn't even lock it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, they said I couldn't lock it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER], That's what they say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give me--I'm going to talk to your supervisor. Give me your supervisor. I want to talk to your supervisor right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, let me get him.Oh, guess who the supervisor is? It's me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, do you have questions?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, get- I want the C.E.O. then.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello.  This is Viacom Services.  How can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hello?  God finally somebody, look, this is ridiculous.  I've been waiting online for like a half an hour now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry ma'am, what can I help you with?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look my, my phone isn't working.  I don't understand what's going on.  I am trying to call out.  I'm not receiving any calls

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and I need assistance with my...not only is my work phone, it's my home phone and look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: this is my business.  This is how I make money is through my phone.  It needs to be working.  Can you please help me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Can you give me the last four digits of your social security number so I can verify who I'm speaking with?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: two two six six.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  And your name is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Olivia.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Olivia. Um. Okay.  So how long has this problem been?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This has been going on for the past two weeks.  I called every single day.  Nobody is helping me.  You guys tell me the same thing over and over, call again, call again, call again--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what exactly is the problem?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't, I don't know what the problem is.  That's what I want you guys to...why is my service not turned on?  And I paid my bills on time.  I don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- I think part of it has to do with the network being down.  It's been having some trouble the last few weeks--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Well that is, that is fine and all.  I don't care.  I really don't care because I want my phone to work that's all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is I am paying you guys for service and I'm not getting any service.  I get, I get just dropped calls all the time and now it's completely not working at all.  I can't even call out, nine one one probably wouldn't even work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I understand--we're not-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Okay.  We're not charging you for any of these months.  We're going to give you three months free.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you better.  You better give me a whole freaking new phone that's what you better do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can give you a new phone--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want a camera phone actually.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can do that.  We can do that.  You just have to sign a one-year contract though with the--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no...  I'm done with these contract business because this is what can happen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You sign the contract and then down the line the phone doesn't work and you're stuck, you can't go to a new...no.  No contracts for me.  You give me a new phone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Besides, it's sort of out of hands at the moment----The whole electrical power outage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want to talk to a supervisor

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would like to talk to your supervisor.  Obviously you're incompetent and don't understand what I'm asking.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- Let me connect you to my supervisor.  Actually, he's out right now so I'm supervisor until he comes back. Um-

dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you could----speak with me some more, you could call back later on maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's ridiculous.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want to call back, you put me on hold for like hours and hours----and it's money, money, money, money and out of my pocket, out of my pocket--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't put you on hold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are a lot of people calling us having problems.  Every phone company is having the same problems ma'am

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every phone...every single phone company?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm hmmm.  Mmm hmmm.  The power outages, everything, hurricane Katrina. Everything's really messed up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is ridiculous.Well what are we supposed to do?  We starve then because I can't use my phone cause

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am a realtor and this is my business.  People are calling me all the time but you know, and I don't have a land line.  I can't afford to have a land line

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: don't you-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm really sorry ma'am.  There's not----a lot we can do for it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That you better be sorry.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you're not helping me at all.  God this is so frustrating.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I can do for you, if you want to make a call right now I could contact you through our computer.  I can call through my phone and you can speak through me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  No.  That's way too complicated.  Look--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you need to fix my phone.  I don't care what you have to do--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry it has to do with an electrical power outage and stuff--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then go up the freaking pole and fix it like, you need to help me.  You don't understand I'm in dire, dire need of a phone right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, okay I'm going to give you a free phone card that you can use at any payphone and that's on us. Okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah yeah, woman going out in South Central on the payphone at night.  Oh that's real safe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm, I'm sorry you chose to live there um--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no.  I didn't choose to live here.  I work there.  Okay?  Yeah. work work work

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I'm sure maybe there's a phone at work you could use.

dialogue.text: We can't call out.  We can't make out-- line.  I don't work, I work at another office.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A law firm.  Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right um--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I work out of my home as a realtor and because I don't have a land line, I need a phone and because of now I don't have one I don't know what to do.  And you're not helping me at all.

dialogue.text: My name is Sara.

dialogue.text: Okay.  Sara what?

dialogue.text: Sara Brown.

dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.text: I have no imagination that's all I know to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is wrong, this chair, this yard.  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.text: Oh, gees.

dialogue.text: It takes a lot of time to toss that off because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I put them in my pocket. that's only a little thing but these are the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I got this idea watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed see, but it seemed to me that there was one new thing that was made

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: a sort of responsibility man for man.  You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There was no meaning in it here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The whole thing to them was sort of a bus accident. Then I went to work with father and that whole rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean you can take those things out of war but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've got to be a little better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: I guess that included you.

dialogue.text: I know. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Yeah, uh. No.

dialogue.text: You- you- you'll find.

dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you have your forms?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let me see them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is there a problem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who told you to get in this line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were standing at the beginning and you directed me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. But I didn't tell you to get in this line if you are filling out this particular form.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what's the problem?  Let me change it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This form is a Z.X.four.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't--  This is not the line for Z.X.four.  If you're going to fill out the Z.X.four, you need to have a different form of ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  I'm getting an ID.  This is why I'm here.  My wallet was stolen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I need another set of ID to prove this is actually you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How am I supposed to get an ID without an ID?  How does a person get an ID in the first place?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I need an ID to pass this form along.  I can't just send it along without an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm here to get an ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I need another ID, a separate one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like what?  Like a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A birth certificate, a passport...a student ID; didn't you go to school?  Anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who the hell has a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes but my wallet was stolen, I don't have anything.  I don't have any credit cards, I don't have my ID.  Don't you have things on file here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  We keep it on file, but we need an ID to access that file.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's out of control.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand why this is so complicated for people when they get here.  It's just a simple form.  I just need an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long have you been working here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually too long.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Clearly.  You know, do you have like a supervisor or something?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Huh? Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Fine.  I'll be right back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That would - I would appreciate that.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What he's going to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here at four this morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up and he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was out here at four this morning I heard a crack and I looked out the window and he was standing right over there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But he went back in the kitchen and he cried.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured I'd just let it wait.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I could hear him crying through the floorboards in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is he doing out here at that hour?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming about him again, walking the streets.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know we've made terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, these kinds of things, man they always come back at you.  And this is definitely coming back to us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean a mistake?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just--why shouldn't he walk the nights waiting for him, huh?  Do we contradict him do we say we don't have any hope any more that he's not coming back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him, it's just for God's sake it's time he realized that no one believes with him any more.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What, can you prove it?  What proof do you have?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years. It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is.  But to your father?  You can talk yourself 'til you're blue in the face but there's was no grave and there is no body.  So where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, all right.  Mom, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is those god damn news papers.  Every month some boy comes back missing longer then Larry so--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, okay all right, all right.  Listen, um, you know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I've got an idea but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do?  You're old enough known your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's okay then?  I'm just going to go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You want to make sure that your father's not going to...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See.  Then it's not just my business. Sometimes you infuriate me, you know that?  You know it's just your business too if I tell father and he throws a fit about it, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.  I ignore what I've got to ignore. That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She is not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of view he is not dead and you have no right to take his girl.  I'm just saying that you can go on from there if you know where to go but I'm saying I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is you know every time I reach out for something I have to pull back 'cause I'm afraid it's going to hurt somebody.  All my life...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I wanted to get this all sorted out first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it.  However from her letters I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm just--I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it I think of her, I grew up next to her.  She is what I think of when I think of a wife.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what that'll do to you, to your father, do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it lots of thought.  And I keep coming back to the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: When I think of a family, when I think of my future I see Annie in the center of that and you know and if that can't happen here then I'll go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll leave.  I'll get married and move somewhere else maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  I said what the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, must you be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes I like it for one hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long when I come home I want it nice, I want a family, I want to kids and Annie is in the center of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If that can't happen here...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me you would leave the business for this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right but you don't think like that because what the hell is this all for.  This is all for you, what are we working for Chris? The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one who still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It kind of went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not so bad; it's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You know, it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not sorry, no. But I'm...I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For one thing, your mother much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And then, you.  You've been kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sort of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I was kind of planning of sneaking up on you over the course of a week or so.  They just take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure, from your mother's point of view.  Why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So would you want to?  I mean, I guess you have to know that's kind of why I asked you to come?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I, umm. I guess, I guess that's kind of why I came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you. Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't really have any imagination, that's all I know how to say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Am I embarrassing you? Are you - See, I didn't want to do it here with this yard, on this porch.  I wanted it to be somewhere new, some place fresh for both of us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel uncomfortable here, you feel that it's wrong here somehow.  I just...I don't...I didn't want...I didn't want to take you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long, time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever?  Are you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.  And when you did finally write me,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie, we are going to live now.  I am going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, let's drive some place.  Huh?  Let's get out of here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's nothing like that. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what?  Chris.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I suppose I have been. But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't even know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just all mixed up with so many other things, you know?  You know overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty much all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't just toss off a thing like that because they weren't just men. You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.  He just put them in my pocket.  That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that, exactly.  Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I had this idea as I was watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed, you know, but this one thing was being made.  It was kind of a monument, it's kind of responsibility, man for man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But then I came home and it was incredible, you know?  The whole thing was just kind of this random bus accident.  You know, I went back to the rat race again, I went to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Driving my new car and seeing a new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way.  Everything you have, you've earned - everything.  you understand me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even me.  And your money?  Chris, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes into the air, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie.  I am going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What would I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at this, all of the hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I was saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think it's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR! Somebody sold you a bunch of crap that there is this wonderful thing that is going to happen tonight on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Not just me, look at all of these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Everybody's told the same story.  It keeps us coming back for more, it keeps us excited.  We keep thinking that life is going start at any minute if we can just find the right spot, get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing, here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, it's just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Now, don't take this the wrong way, but are you on your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that, you always ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then, what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas of what this night is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There is nothing to it; we come down here, the fish arrive, they flop around, they do their fish thing.  We go ooh, ah, look at the fish and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God- Grow up, Augie.  The fish are not going to arrive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because they never do.  Have they...Have they ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we have tried; that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They'll show up this time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No they won't.  It's like waiting for Santa Claus.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like my whole life is going to be spent standing on this beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for fish to show up.  And the fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I am saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. Of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it, I still do, I always do.  I just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm always just standing here waiting.  I feel like this night is going to be the night, but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish, it's nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm trying to work this backwards and pinpoint the exact moment where we took a turn for the worst here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So you were fine during that phone call from Marge and then dinner was okay.  And doing the dishes was fine and then I was going to take a shower and you're watching the news and you said the grunions are running tonight, do you want to go?  And I said, sure great, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So I am putting out the pets, getting the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first year we came here?  It was like four years after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant, we got a bottle of champagne, we had no glasses.  We took off our shoes and you asked me to dance.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You whispered the sweetest, most intimate things to me right into my ear so I could feel them as much as hear them.  And I remember thinking, this is it.  You know, finally, I am as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Drinking champagne from the bottle,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's when we were driving past that Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said, let's get some champagne.  I said no, time's a wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: dancing barefoot in the sand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's what it is?  Right?  You want this to be like the other time, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember some things.  I'd rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure.  All right.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to go get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to take off your shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no. Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  What?  Do you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like a new carpet?  A poodle?  A back rub?  Ice cream?  A suicide pact?  What do you want?  What the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just want something to turn out like I expected it to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race, huh?  Do you think I had some grand fantasy going that four years down the line we would come to this beach and be arguing over fish?  No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: No I'm just like you.  I thought it was going to be all roses and peaches and the bills would just pay themselves.  And we'll have three, fat rosy cheeked children.  Huh, baby, the joke's on us.  Because you know what you get?

dialogue.text: Do you know what you get?  You get this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This? What is this?  This is nothing.  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure.  This is standing on the beach waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean this is a lot of things, but it's just...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you understand what I am saying?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are Augie, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you meant this to be special, I know that you wanted it to be right, but I just can't help thinking that, I can't help wishing that I was somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just- I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be ridiculous.  Anything that- anything I am doing, I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For Heaven's sake Augie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the one who probably wishes he was with somebody else.  Somebody who doesn't take things so seriously, who could enjoy herself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, actually now that you mention it, no I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So maybe we are in the wrong spot, but we are with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it seemed like such a good spot to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We have a great view of the moon from here, though, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  I noticed that, it's pretty. Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And look what I got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you bought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: Do you want to go home?  Are you cold?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, I mean, I just don't think...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean I've been sending out my resumes and doing everything I can do but nothing is happening.  You know, it's like I can't and I can't keep living on loans anymore like this.  I'm going to--I mean eventually I'm going to have to pay it back. I'm just kind of freaking out, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ever think it might be your attitude that's...

dialogue.text: I don't know just sometimes you get kind of... No, I'm not saying that.  I just--

dialogue.text: Do I have an attitude problem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, well maybe it's because I'm like frustrated 'cause I can't get a job, you know.

dialogue.text: Right, sure.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm just saying though that if I was a person who was hiring somebody I-- --would not hire someone who was angry or upset.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I come across angry?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you know a little.  If you were to listen to--

dialogue.text: Okay.  You're my friend you can tell me stuff.  You can tell me honestly stuff, okay?  Please.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't want you to fly off the handle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, I'm not flying off the handle I don't think I'm flying off the handle here at all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You kind of have a short fuse.

dialogue.text: I have a short fuse?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Okay no, no, no, no okay no, I need to hear this more. Come on, bring it.

dialogue.text: We're trying to have a conversation and you seem extremely hostile. You keep cutting me off.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, it's 'cause I can't get a job, okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not always right I'm just--

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and you're always right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: fine okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have an excuse for everything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: I'm just saying that maybe you should take in some information before you produce more of your own.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm like a sponge I'm like soaked up with all this information for like three years I'm just dying for a job to like put it in to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's -.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what kind of field are you looking to go into?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, uh, so how's it been going?  I mean, you have any needs or anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm--every lead that I get ends up just being a dead end.  You know what I mean.  People are sick of me calling--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You can't think that way.  I mean it's good--it's good that you're--that you're calling, you know. you can't

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, we're not hiring at this time or thank you, we already have your information on file--We'll call you when we're ready.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah--I know what you mean.  I've gone through like similar stuff, but--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, come on.  Don't [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just--I can't do it anymore.  Like, it just takes it out of you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I know. It's hard, but you just--you gotta keep going.  I mean, you've been going at it for so long, you know.  Something is definitely going to come up.  I-I know it will, because you're a good worker--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just keep getting rejected.  I just keep getting rejected over and over and over again and it starts to make you feel like there must be something wrong with you that you can't get a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  It's--I mean, it's competitive, you know.  That's-That's what it is.  that's what you gotta be is competitive.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but maybe--if just because it's competitive, like maybe I'm just not good enough.  Maybe the level is here and I'm here and there's just no way I'm ever gonna do that--

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...dumber than you.  I mean they're a lot worse off than you.  You are much better off than like a lot of those people in there. I know

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It makes it harder.  I mean it's definitely who you know in a lot of cases, but--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's just so frustrating.  Like, I just--I just don't wanna do it anymore.  You know?  I just don't wanna like hit the pavement every single day with my resumes and going out there all the time.  You know, it's just like--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel so worthless.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not worthless 'cause it's definitely gonna--it's definitely gonna pay off.  I know it.  I mean, I can--I've just--I've seen your work etiquette.  You know, you're a good worker and...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ... and there's no reason that--that something won't come up like really soon.  All right?  So you just gotta--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what would make you say that?  There doesn't seem to be any indicators that anything's going to get better.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because I know you.  You know, and maybe once you get to know some more people, like talking to them and everything, they'll get to know you too and they'll realize they should've hired you three years ago. Like it's like suddenly it starts to feel like it's just you that they say no to and it's not that they're not taking applications and it's not that they're not hiring people, it's just you particularly they have some particular reason for just hating you.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe yeah, but maybe you get to that point where it's like you bug 'em and then they just don't wanna hear from you anymore, but you keep bugging them and bugging them and then it's gonna annoy them so much that they're gonna be like all right fine. you know

dialogue.text: That obviously that's not true though.  I mean, you've done this before.  You've done all the work like this before, you know, and and you've gotten people saying oh, you're so good and like you know--

dialogue.text: I guess the money shouldn't matter to me, but--Somehow it does.  You know? It's not like I do it for the money, but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you have to--I mean, if you're hired by somebody, then you're not a professional, you're an amateur and that means that you're not good enough.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
