dialogue.text: It's just really hard.  I feel like their starting to get like a personal prejudice against me.  You know what I mean?  Like it's like suddenly it starts to feel like it's just you that they say no to and it's not that they're not taking applications and it's not that they're not hiring people, it's just you particularly they have some particular reason for just hating you.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe yeah, but maybe you get to that point where it's like you bug 'em and then they just don't wanna hear from you anymore, but you keep bugging them and bugging them and then it's gonna annoy them so much that they're gonna be like all right fine. you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or they'll never talk to me again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or, well, no.  Okay. you -[GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I-I just I think maybe I should try something else.  I mean, I-I don't know.  All growing up this is the only thing that I ever wanted to do and yet I can't.  I'm not physically able apparently.  I mean--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That obviously that's not true though.  I mean, you've done this before.  You've done all the work like this before, you know, and and you've gotten people saying oh, you're so good and like you know--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess the money shouldn't matter to me, but--Somehow it does.  You know? It's not like I do it for the money, but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you've gotta live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you have to--I mean, if you're hired by somebody, then you're not a professional, you're an amateur and that means that you're not good enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, it's just, it's really--I don't know, yeah, it's about their opinions and it's about, I don't know, just getting yourself out there and--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just wanna crawl in a hole, you know.  Like it just makes you not wanna even open your eyes in the morning.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, come on, come on.  Thinking about it like this is definitely not gonna help either though.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know how to get out of it.  I don't know how to dig myself out of it.  It's the same hole that I've been digging and digging and digging.  I can't--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he gonna say?  Maybe we ought to tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up, he was still in bed.

dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four this morning.  I heard it cracking and I woke up and looked out. He was standing right here when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  When it cracked, he ran back in the house and cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I thought it was best to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear him right through the floor of my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at that hour?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming about him again.  He's walking around at night.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like after he died.  What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But, I know one thing Mom, we made a terrible mistake with Dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  I mean, that sort of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I don't want to argue with him, but it's about time he realized that nobody believes Larry's alive anymore?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he dream of him and walk the nights waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can you prove it?  How can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God sakes, it's been three years.  Nobody comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.  I mean, you can talk yourself blue in the face, but he--there's no body and no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Trouble is the God damn newspapers.  Every month or so a boy turns up out of nowhere so, you know, the next one is gonna be Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's all right then?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't going to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, then it isn't just my business--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, sometimes you infuriate me.  You know that?  I mean, isn't it your business too if I tell Dad and flips--freaks out about it?  I mean, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I gotta ignore.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he isn't dead.  And you've no right to take his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.  Now what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why, but, every time I reach out for something that I want, I have to pull back 'cause someone else will suffer.  My whole bloody life.  Time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong with that.

dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she'll marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.text: Trouble is, you don't see enough women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what, I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything.  I mean, you've been away for--at war.  It's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it.  I know her best.  I mean, I grew up next door to her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: These years when I think of a wife, I think of Annie.  What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.  Umm-- He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl and you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, what's gonna happen to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right, then, Mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just--give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  I thought that if I waited Dad would forget about Larry and we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't--if that can't happen here, then I'll have to get out.

dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and go live some place else.  Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long.  A good sucker.  I'm through with it.

dialogue.text: What about the business?  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it an hour a day.  If I'm gonna grub for my money all day long, at least in the evening I want it beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want a family.  I want kids.  I want something that I can give myself to.  Annie's in the middle of that.  Now, where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me, you'd leave the business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right, but just don't go thinkin' like that 'cause otherwise what did we work for?  I mean, the whole thing is for you, Chris.  The whole shootin' match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I know, Mom.  Just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  Just-- just don't go thinkin' that way, you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinkin' that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you're never going to believe it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What? What? You look really happy what's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I finally did it

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Finally did what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I asked her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You did? Oh, my Gosh, I'm so proud of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I know. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my Gosh. Well, and did

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm so nervous you know, I'm-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did she say yes?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, she said yes. [LAUGHTER] I know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's like the most definitive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know Uhm- I can't believe it.  It's like-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my gosh, wait so when did you decide to do this, I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would have thought you would have told me that you were planning on doing this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, yes, I wanted it you know I guess sort of as a surprise for everyone so

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, I guess so. Oh, my Gosh. Was she surprised?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. You know, she - she was like - I mean, she was happy, you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I - I think it was about time, I don't know, maybe. You know what, it's been it's been long enough now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So what did you do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, well, it was -- you know, we were at this- at this concert and yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so I-I talked to some of the crew before hand and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, You did not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my Gosh. that's so cute

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So I got the band to do something, you know, like towards the end of the song I got to go up on stage and, uh

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's so romantic. Oh, my Gosh. She must have died. That's like one of those things you write into a magazine about like my boyfriend did this. Oh my God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, so

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got to freak her out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, yes -- so

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She must have flipped out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, that way she was guaranteed that she could not say no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right exactly because you can't say no in front of thousands of people. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, but it was good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you bring her up on stage too?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my Gosh, that's so cute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know it was, I don't know I was really nervous but I'm really - I'm really glad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are your parents excited or...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yes, they - they you know they love her and so I mean...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, totally. So when is it going to happen?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, we're thinking uh - we're thinking winter time, you know, we're going to do it in the winter and then maybe, you know, maybe

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know either do a honeymoon like in the snow or fly down to like Australia, Southern Hemisphere, [GARBAGE] so we'll decide with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ooh, that would be fun.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think you'll get a house or something, like you guys are looking to buy some place or

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, yea, I'm not too sure where yet I guess you know, I kind of got to figure some stuff out here first

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: but like you know it's just - I guess we're just excited right now that we'll get to continue it together.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my Gosh. I cannot believe you're getting married, that is so cool.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Golly, it just makes me all like romantic inside, like I really want that to happen to me. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, it will, obviously you know. But I know it's something - I don't know, you never really think about it happening, like before hand.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you have a good ring? You better have had a good ring.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure. Oh, yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Good. The ring makes all the difference.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I had my mom come along maybe help me out a little bit because she's got good taste. but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, that's awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, well, Thanks, thanks. Thank you. yeah

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yay, well congratulations, that's so cool. [BREATHING] I can't wait.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, nobody know we're here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Must be them, then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What're we gonna do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right, darling, aren't we?  Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello?  Hello?  What?  Wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ah, it send shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do we do if they suddenly walk in on us?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With the most perfect poise?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, of course.  I shall probably do a court curtsy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Things that ought to matter dreadfully don't matter at all when one's happy.  Do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's so horrible is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true.  The whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Meaning that sacred and beautiful thing, love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, what does it all mean?  That's what I ask myself in my ceaseless quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God, what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mustn't be serious, my dear one.  That's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All those futile moralists that try to make life unbearable.  Laugh at them.  Be flippant.  Laugh at everything.  All their sacred shibboleths.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If I laugh at everything, then I must laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly, you must.  We're figures of fun, alright.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how long will it last us, this ludicrous overbearing love of ours.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, that desire will fade.  Along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear, shall we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we've played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what happens if one of us dies?  I mean, does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  Yes. With all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No, it isn't.  Death is very laughable.  Such a cunning little mystery.  All done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.  Let's blow our trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party as much as we can.  Like quite idiotic, very small school children.  Let's savor the delight of the moment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come and kiss me, darling, before your body rots and worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do.  See, you could paint yourself green and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word.  As long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you, dear.  The same applies to you except that if I catch so much as looking at another woman, I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it on my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Charles.  That was his name.  Charles.  He did wriggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, horrible thing.  I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I know you did.  You threw it out of the window into the Grand Canal.  I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went in intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your curling iron burnt a hole in my new dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It burned my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling around on the floor, biting and scratching like panthers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I'll never forget his face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was ridiculous.  Completely ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I was saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly it's not. Slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR. Someone sold you a bill of goods that this wonderful event is going to take place on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'm not the only one look at all these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, sure everyone was sold the same story. I mean it keeps us all excited, keeps us coming back for more, keeps us thinking that life is going to start any second now if we can just get in on the action and find the right spot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry but it's still just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something? Don't take this wrong but are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Goddamn it Augie don't ask me that. I hate it when you ask me that. You always ask me that. It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas of what this evening is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There is nothing to it, we come here, the Grunion arrive, then do their little fish business, we go oh ah look, they go home, we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heavens sake we are not going to see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We never do, do we? I mean have we ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice; that's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we've tried, that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, we'll see them this year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No we won't; it's pointless. It's like waiting up to see Santa Claus,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean I feel like my whole life is going to be spent standing on the beach waiting for the fish to show up with my eyes open and my hands clasped expectantly and the fish won't show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I'm saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see them, I always do. I mean I keep thinking that this is going to be the time and it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish, I mean nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heavens sake this isn't about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. I've been trying to work this backwards but I cannot seem to pinpoint the moment that we took a turn for the worst.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You were fine during the phone call from Marge, dinner was okay, doing the dishes was no problem, let's see, I took a shower, you watched the news, you said

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: "the Grunion are running tonight," I said "great, let's go, I feel lucky,"

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay so I'm getting on my jacket and putting out the animals, getting the car out of the garage-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first time we came to see it? It was about four years ago right after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant and we opened a bottle of champagne but no glasses, you asked me to dance, we kicked off our shoes and you popped the cork.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And when we were dancing you said the softest most intimate things to me right into my ears so I could feel them as much as hear them

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and I remember thinking that this is it you know. At last, at last I am as happy as I am supposed to be

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute I've got it

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just dancing barefoot in the sand, drinking champagne out of the bottle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was in the car, right? Driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker you said, let's get some champagne and I said times are wasting or something like that, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, I see it now; you want this to be like that other time, right? That's it, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember some things. I would rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea. Okay, sure, no. I see. Listen, you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want to go get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, you want me to breathe in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? What? You want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A new carpet? A poodle, a ice cream, backrub, a suicide pact, what, what Carla, what the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want something to turn out the way that it supposed to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race, all right. Do you think this is what I had in mind when I proposed? You think I had this great fantasy going that four years down the road we'd come to the beach and yell at each other over fish?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think I knew that there be times when you'd look at me like I'm a used Kleenex, or that I'd look at you and think holy hell when is the next flight to Alaska?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, just like you I thought it was going to be all like peaches and roses and sand in our toes, and wind in our hair, and the fish will always come and the bills will pay themselves and we'll have three, fat, rosy kids and ha-ha baby the joke is on us

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: 'cause you know what you get Carla, you know what you get? This.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This? What, what is this? This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sure, this is standing on the beach, this is waiting, this is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, but this isn't anything like I thought anything would be like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know. Me neither.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean it's -- this is just this. I mean it includes a lot and everything but isn't something else. Do you have any idea what I'm trying to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know that Augie. Really I do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know that you meant this to be special and nice, and there's the sand and the moon and everything but I just couldn't help thinking about being somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with somebody else too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know. But still, I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heavens sake, whatever I'm doing I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be ridiculous. I mean don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the one who probably wishes he was with someone else, someone who knew how to enjoy herself and didn't take everything so hard.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now that you mention it. No, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Fine, so we're in the wrong spot but we're with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know it seemed like a pretty good spot to me. Look at the moon - view the moon view I got from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I noticed that. It looks pretty on the water doesn't it? Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have we got here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you brought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You still cold? Do you want my jacket? Do you want to go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No. I think you might be right. I think this may be the spot after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh, if we're very quiet the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York for three and half years.  Why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe he just wanted to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  He lived next door to the girl all his life.  Why wouldn't he want to see her again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anymore than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -he's not gonna marry her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that all about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, listen Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not his girl, Joe.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then why is she still single?  I mean, New York is full of men.  Why isn't she married?  Probably a hundred people told her she's crazy, but she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my worst moments I think of her waiting and I know again that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, it's a nice day.  What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take her faith away, Joe?  Strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to act like he's coming back.  Both of you.  Don't you think I haven't noticed since she got here.  I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But Kate--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  I mean, laugh--laugh at me, but...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But why did that happen the very night she came here?  She sleeps in his room and his memorial breaks to pieces.  Just look.  Look at it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last week, a man turned up in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  I mean, you read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right.  Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You, above all, have to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?- Why- Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just--just don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean?  Me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you.  Look at you shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents, just a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I remember it well, bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it wasn't. It was very pretty I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I didn't, you worked the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you; you said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot of pleasure, it didn't hurt me any.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so nosey and suspicious you never wouldn't have known anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored of this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, me too, bored stiff. You want some Brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have a little I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want any you've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason. Anyhow, they are very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It just seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because don't happen want any yourself right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I'm just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a woman's job to allure the man

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, no it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have any more Brandy it might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It doesn't seem to work such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh nonsense they have a little bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. Do you understand? I don't care. I don't care if they bark or roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Tell me, did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine you let him kiss you good deal more then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What riotous time you must have had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No restraint at all, very enjoyable, never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable. I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not in the least drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine, as I may have already mentioned, I've had three minute liquor glasses of Brandy the whole evening long a child of two couldn't get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary a child of two could get violently drunk on only one glass of Brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh very interesting. How about a child of four, a child of six or a child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can get a good little debate going about that, don't you think? Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny my dear, you better have some more Brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Better turn that off I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it's late and it'll annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs it's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are people downstairs I suppose?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well, if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off it's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental. Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. Stop it. I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen indeed. I'm sick and tired of listening to you, damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. Stop it. I hate you, do you hear? You're overbearing and conceited and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a vile tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I hope I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end, do you hear? The end finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I am. Let go of me you're cruel fiend and I hate and loathe you. Thank God I realized who you really are before I would ever, ever marry you again. I would never marry you again. I'd rather die in torment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you again if you came to me on your bended knees. You're a evil minded little vampire. I hope to God I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a beast. I hate you. Stop it. Stop it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey listen here missy, I've been in this line for an hour and now I'm finally here.  So you're going to take my application.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is that a demand sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not a demand it's a request.  Will you just take it?  Come on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I must see it before I just take it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Look at it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, you completely filled this out wrong.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  You filled out the back part.  You were supposed to fill out the front portion only.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What are you talking about?  It says fill out that part.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no.  You're going to have to go back over on the other side-- --second door, up the stairs...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God. Can you just transfer it yourself?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I can't just transfer it myself sir.  You got to do this.  Everyone else is doing the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: What?  I'm getting an ID.  This is why I'm here.  My wallet was stolen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I need another set of ID to prove this is actually you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How am I supposed to get an ID without an ID?  How does a person get an ID in the first place?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I need an ID to pass this form along.  I can't just send it along without an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm here to get an ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I need another ID, a separate one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like what?  Like a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A birth certificate, a passport...a student ID; didn't you go to school?  Anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who the hell has a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes but my wallet was stolen, I don't have anything.  I don't have any credit cards, I don't have my ID.  Don't you have things on file here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  We keep it on file, but we need an ID to access that file.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's out of control.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand why this is so complicated for people when they get here.  It's just a simple form.  I just need an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long have you been working here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually too long.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Clearly.  You know, do you have like a supervisor or something?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Huh? Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Fine.  I'll be right back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That would - I would appreciate that.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What he's going to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here at four this morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up and he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was out here at four this morning I heard a crack and I looked out the window and he was standing right over there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But he went back in the kitchen and he cried.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured I'd just let it wait.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I could hear him crying through the floorboards in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is he doing out here at that hour?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming about him again, walking the streets.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know we've made terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, these kinds of things, man they always come back at you.  And this is definitely coming back to us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean a mistake?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just--why shouldn't he walk the nights waiting for him, huh?  Do we contradict him do we say we don't have any hope any more that he's not coming back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him, it's just for God's sake it's time he realized that no one believes with him any more.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What, can you prove it?  What proof do you have?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years. It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is.  But to your father?  You can talk yourself 'til you're blue in the face but there's was no grave and there is no body.  So where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, all right.  Mom, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is those god damn news papers.  Every month some boy comes back missing longer then Larry so--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, okay all right, all right.  Listen, um, you know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I've got an idea but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do?  You're old enough known your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's okay then?  I'm just going to go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You want to make sure that your father's not going to...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See.  Then it's not just my business. Sometimes you infuriate me, you know that?  You know it's just your business too if I tell father and he throws a fit about it, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.  I ignore what I've got to ignore. That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She is not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of view he is not dead and you have no right to take his girl.  I'm just saying that you can go on from there if you know where to go but I'm saying I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is you know every time I reach out for something I have to pull back 'cause I'm afraid it's going to hurt somebody.  All my life...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I wanted to get this all sorted out first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it.  However from her letters I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm just--I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it I think of her, I grew up next to her.  She is what I think of when I think of a wife.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what that'll do to you, to your father, do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it lots of thought.  And I keep coming back to the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: When I think of a family, when I think of my future I see Annie in the center of that and you know and if that can't happen here then I'll go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll leave.  I'll get married and move somewhere else maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  I said what the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, must you be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes I like it for one hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long when I come home I want it nice, I want a family, I want to kids and Annie is in the center of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If that can't happen here...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me you would leave the business for this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right but you don't think like that because what the hell is this all for.  This is all for you, what are we working for Chris? The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one who still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It kind of went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not so bad; it's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You know, it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not sorry, no. But I'm...I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For one thing, your mother much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And then, you.  You've been kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sort of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I was kind of planning of sneaking up on you over the course of a week or so.  They just take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure, from your mother's point of view.  Why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So would you want to?  I mean, I guess you have to know that's kind of why I asked you to come?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I, umm. I guess, I guess that's kind of why I came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you. Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't really have any imagination, that's all I know how to say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Am I embarrassing you? Are you - See, I didn't want to do it here with this yard, on this porch.  I wanted it to be somewhere new, some place fresh for both of us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel uncomfortable here, you feel that it's wrong here somehow.  I just...I don't...I didn't want...I didn't want to take you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long, time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever?  Are you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.  And when you did finally write me,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie, we are going to live now.  I am going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, let's drive some place.  Huh?  Let's get out of here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's nothing like that. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what?  Chris.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I suppose I have been. But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't even know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just all mixed up with so many other things, you know?  You know overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty much all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't just toss off a thing like that because they weren't just men. You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.  He just put them in my pocket.  That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that, exactly.  Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I had this idea as I was watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed, you know, but this one thing was being made.  It was kind of a monument, it's kind of responsibility, man for man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But then I came home and it was incredible, you know?  The whole thing was just kind of this random bus accident.  You know, I went back to the rat race again, I went to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Driving my new car and seeing a new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way.  Everything you have, you've earned - everything.  you understand me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even me.  And your money?  Chris, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes into the air, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie.  I am going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What would I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at this, all of the hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I was saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think it's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR! Somebody sold you a bunch of crap that there is this wonderful thing that is going to happen tonight on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Not just me, look at all of these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Everybody's told the same story.  It keeps us coming back for more, it keeps us excited.  We keep thinking that life is going start at any minute if we can just find the right spot, get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing, here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, it's just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Now, don't take this the wrong way, but are you on your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that, you always ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then, what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas of what this night is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There is nothing to it; we come down here, the fish arrive, they flop around, they do their fish thing.  We go ooh, ah, look at the fish and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God- Grow up, Augie.  The fish are not going to arrive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because they never do.  Have they...Have they ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we have tried; that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They'll show up this time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No they won't.  It's like waiting for Santa Claus.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like my whole life is going to be spent standing on this beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for fish to show up.  And the fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I am saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. Of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it, I still do, I always do.  I just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm always just standing here waiting.  I feel like this night is going to be the night, but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish, it's nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm trying to work this backwards and pinpoint the exact moment where we took a turn for the worst here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So you were fine during that phone call from Marge and then dinner was okay.  And doing the dishes was fine and then I was going to take a shower and you're watching the news and you said the grunions are running tonight, do you want to go?  And I said, sure great, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So I am putting out the pets, getting the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first year we came here?  It was like four years after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant, we got a bottle of champagne, we had no glasses.  We took off our shoes and you asked me to dance.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You whispered the sweetest, most intimate things to me right into my ear so I could feel them as much as hear them.  And I remember thinking, this is it.  You know, finally, I am as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Drinking champagne from the bottle,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's when we were driving past that Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said, let's get some champagne.  I said no, time's a wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: dancing barefoot in the sand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's what it is?  Right?  You want this to be like the other time, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember some things.  I'd rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure.  All right.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to go get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to take off your shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no. Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  What?  Do you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like a new carpet?  A poodle?  A back rub?  Ice cream?  A suicide pact?  What do you want?  What the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just want something to turn out like I expected it to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race, huh?  Do you think I had some grand fantasy going that four years down the line we would come to this beach and be arguing over fish?  No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I'm just like you.  I thought it was going to be all roses and peaches and the bills would just pay themselves.  And we'll have three, fat rosy cheeked children.  Huh, baby, the joke's on us.  Because you know what you get?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you know what you get?  You get this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This? What is this?  This is nothing.  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure.  This is standing on the beach waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean this is a lot of things, but it's just...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you understand what I am saying?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are Augie, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you meant this to be special, I know that you wanted it to be right, but I just can't help thinking that, I can't help wishing that I was somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with someone else, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just- I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be ridiculous.  Anything that- anything I am doing, I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For Heaven's sake Augie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the one who probably wishes he was with somebody else.  Somebody who doesn't take things so seriously, who could enjoy herself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, actually now that you mention it, no I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So maybe we are in the wrong spot, but we are with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it seemed like such a good spot to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We have a great view of the moon from here, though, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  I noticed that, it's pretty. Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And look what I got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you bought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to go home?  Are you cold?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm beginning to think this might be the right spot after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.  If we're very quiet, the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and an half years, why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe...maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  You know he lived next door to the girl his whole life, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She is not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men, why is she still single?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my darkest moments, I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey look, it's a nice day, huh?  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith, Joe.  You know strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to-- I want you to act like he is coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since Chris invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  Oh laugh, laugh all you like but why does this happen the very night he comes back.  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just believe with me, Joe. Only last week a man came back in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  Believe with me. You, above all, have got to believe. Just believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You seem kind of down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's--I've been trying to find this job I can't get any job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean I've been looking for a job for like three years and I can't get a job.  I mean like, it's America, right?  I should be able to get a job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's a lot of people looking for jobs.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess.  But three years?  I mean, I like--I went to college even, I mean I didn't finish but I went for like a little bit.  It's not fair, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, I mean, I just don't think...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean I've been sending out my resumes and doing everything I can do but nothing is happening.  You know, it's like I can't and I can't keep living on loans anymore like this.  I'm going to--I mean eventually I'm going to have to pay it back. I'm just kind of freaking out, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ever think it might be your attitude that's...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's my--like what do you mean "my attitude"?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know just sometimes you get kind of... No, I'm not saying that.  I just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do I have an attitude problem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, well maybe it's because I'm like frustrated 'cause I can't get a job, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...has anyone ever just said anything like that to you before?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like it's really hard to like shake that off when you go into like audition a room or whatever, you know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right, sure.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But I mean you kind of got to, you got to fake it 'til you feel it, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess I just getting really hard to fake, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying that if I was looking to hire somebody in the--or kind of... No. No. No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you hiring? Wait, do you know of a job? Seriously, do you know, like do you know of anything though?  Like, oh please, do you know of anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm just saying though that if I was a person who was hiring somebody I-- --would not hire someone who was angry or upset.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I come across angry?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you know a little.  If you were to listen to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  You're my friend you can tell me stuff.  You can tell me honestly stuff, okay?  Please.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't want you to fly off the handle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, I'm not flying off the handle I don't think I'm flying off the handle here at all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You kind of have a short fuse.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have a short fuse?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Okay no, no, no, no okay no, I need to hear this more. Come on, bring it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like this, right now we're trying have a conversation.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We're trying to have a conversation and you seem extremely hostile. You keep cutting me off.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, it's 'cause I can't get a job, okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not always right I'm just--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't finish the sentence with you without you jumping in...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and you're always right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: fine okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have an excuse for everything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying that maybe you should take in some information before you produce more of your own.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm like a sponge I'm like soaked up with all this information for like three years I'm just dying for a job to like put it in to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's -.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, and like I don't think it's that much to ask. I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what kind of field are you looking to go into?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, uh, so how's it been going?  I mean, you have any needs or anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm--every lead that I get ends up just being a dead end.  You know what I mean.  People are sick of me calling--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You can't think that way.  I mean it's good--it's good that you're--that you're calling, you know. you can't

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but it--I mean it's the same response you get over and over again.  Like--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, we're not hiring at this time or thank you, we already have your information on file--We'll call you when we're ready.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah--I know what you mean.  I've gone through like similar stuff, but--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, it's been so long, like--I mine as well just take a job at McDonald's.  Like, I don't--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, come on.  Don't [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just--I can't do it anymore.  Like, it just takes it out of you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I know. It's hard, but you just--you gotta keep going.  I mean, you've been going at it for so long, you know.  Something is definitely going to come up.  I-I know it will, because you're a good worker--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just keep getting rejected.  I just keep getting rejected over and over and over again and it starts to make you feel like there must be something wrong with you that you can't get a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  It's--I mean, it's competitive, you know.  That's-That's what it is.  that's what you gotta be is competitive.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but maybe--if just because it's competitive, like maybe I'm just not good enough.  Maybe the level is here and I'm here and there's just no way I'm ever gonna do that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There...There are plenty of people out there with--with like, good jobs, you know, that are a lot...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...dumber than you.  I mean they're a lot worse off than you.  You are much better off than like a lot of those people in there. I know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't have like one of those starts, you know, like a family member who was already in the business or something you know that could like give me a helping hand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It makes it harder.  I mean it's definitely who you know in a lot of cases, but--

dialogue.speaker: F
