dialogue.text: No, I know. But still, I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heavens sake, whatever I'm doing I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be ridiculous. I mean don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the one who probably wishes he was with someone else, someone who knew how to enjoy herself and didn't take everything so hard.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now that you mention it. No, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Fine, so we're in the wrong spot but we're with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know it seemed like a pretty good spot to me. Look at the moon - view the moon view I got from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I noticed that. It looks pretty on the water doesn't it? Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have we got here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you brought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You still cold? Do you want my jacket? Do you want to go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No. I think you might be right. I think this may be the spot after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh, if we're very quiet the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York for three and half years.  Why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe he just wanted to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  He lived next door to the girl all his life.  Why wouldn't he want to see her again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anymore than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -he's not gonna marry her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that all about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, listen Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not his girl, Joe.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then why is she still single?  I mean, New York is full of men.  Why isn't she married?  Probably a hundred people told her she's crazy, but she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my worst moments I think of her waiting and I know again that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, it's a nice day.  What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take her faith away, Joe?  Strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to act like he's coming back.  Both of you.  Don't you think I haven't noticed since she got here.  I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But Kate--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  I mean, laugh--laugh at me, but...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But why did that happen the very night she came here?  She sleeps in his room and his memorial breaks to pieces.  Just look.  Look at it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last week, a man turned up in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  I mean, you read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right.  Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You, above all, have to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?- Why- Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just--just don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean?  Me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you.  Look at you shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents, just a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I remember it well, bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it wasn't. It was very pretty I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I didn't, you worked the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you; you said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot of pleasure, it didn't hurt me any.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so nosey and suspicious you never wouldn't have known anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored of this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, me too, bored stiff. You want some Brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have a little I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want any you've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason. Anyhow, they are very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It just seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because don't happen want any yourself right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I'm just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a woman's job to allure the man

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, no it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have any more Brandy it might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It doesn't seem to work such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh nonsense they have a little bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. Do you understand? I don't care. I don't care if they bark or roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Tell me, did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine you let him kiss you good deal more then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What riotous time you must have had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No restraint at all, very enjoyable, never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable. I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not in the least drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine, as I may have already mentioned, I've had three minute liquor glasses of Brandy the whole evening long a child of two couldn't get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary a child of two could get violently drunk on only one glass of Brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh very interesting. How about a child of four, a child of six or a child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can get a good little debate going about that, don't you think? Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny my dear, you better have some more Brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Better turn that off I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it's late and it'll annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs it's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are people downstairs I suppose?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well, if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off it's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental. Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. Stop it. I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen indeed. I'm sick and tired of listening to you, damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. Stop it. I hate you, do you hear? You're overbearing and conceited and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a vile tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I hope I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end, do you hear? The end finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I am. Let go of me you're cruel fiend and I hate and loathe you. Thank God I realized who you really are before I would ever, ever marry you again. I would never marry you again. I'd rather die in torment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you again if you came to me on your bended knees. You're a evil minded little vampire. I hope to God I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a beast. I hate you. Stop it. Stop it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey listen here missy, I've been in this line for an hour and now I'm finally here.  So you're going to take my application.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is that a demand sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not a demand it's a request.  Will you just take it?  Come on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I must see it before I just take it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Look at it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, you completely filled this out wrong.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  You filled out the back part.  You were supposed to fill out the front portion only.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What are you talking about?  It says fill out that part.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no.  You're going to have to go back over on the other side-- --second door, up the stairs...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God. Can you just transfer it yourself?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I can't just transfer it myself sir.  You got to do this.  Everyone else is doing the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know! you can't write?  You don't know how to write?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's wrong with you people?  God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think you're being a little condescending.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You need to go back over there and fill it out again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The information is on there.  Here I'll just fill it out right here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no, because there are other people in line.  You have to go get a complete new application.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This will take like a minute, okay? Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no. Sir,you need to get out of the line--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not going anywhere.  I'm staying right here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm going to have to call- security because sir, you- there are hundreds of people waiting in line at this D.M.V.-- --We're closing in about half an hour...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey,uh-- Well that's too bad cause I'm getting my license right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You will get your license, sir, you have to go fill out-- --another copy...excuse me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me my--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, no, give me that back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  Now I'm going to take this from you because you are obviously misleading

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -- No.  I'm not waiting...I'm not coming back again.  I don't have time to come back five days.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  You couldn't go get another one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then you won't have a license will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a license.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well not from this department you won't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes I will.  I'll have this [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: just as I want.  Ugh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir?  I'm going to ask you one more time and then I'm going to call my supervisor

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: who will proceed to call-- security if you can't remove yourself--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Fine.  Call your supervisor.  Ask supervisor over

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and I'll tell her how you've been behaving.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How would you like that hmm?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not actually in the building.  She's only on the phone. Sir, please leave this line immediately.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, okay.  Wow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I'm not going anywhere.  I'm staying here-- I am filling out right now okay just calm down. I'm filling out right now-- Just take the god damn piece of paper.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm going to call security. Security!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have it.  I'm taking it.  Doesn't mean I'm going to do anything with it.--Get out of my line!  This is my line.  Get out.  All these people--Sir, you are causing a mob in this department.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okey This is a new one.  Take the new one.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you own the D.M.V.?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry she's--these people they just want to get their license--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, You cannot get your license.  You filled out the wrong part of the form.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What are you talking about?  Just transfer it over.  I filled out the new one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This entire time you're fighting with me sir, you could've finished the form and already been half way-- No.  Get out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I did finish one.  Take it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can I help you sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes you can help me.  Where is my luggage?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, let me just check on that for you.  Where are you coming--?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  You do that.  I'm coming from Baltimore.  You know where that is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, yes it's in Maryland.  It's okay...well, I'm...just let me check here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I had eight hundred pounds of luggage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Sir?  Can you...if you just give me one moment and let me just check okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Check.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright.  And you're coming-- Wait, hold on sir.  You're coming from Baltimore into LAX right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it there?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay and this is direct flight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know where we're at?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm asking you if this is direct flight from Baltimore to LAX or if you have to stop--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I've been waiting here for four hours for my luggage

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and it's not here, they told me to go to this person, go to this person.  Now I'm at this person.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're at me and I'm going to try to help you out sir but you just have to cooperate with me--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many pieces of luggage do you have checked in?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Eight.  And they're all gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Eight pieces of luggage.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what are you going to do about it?  You going to call someone?  You going to send me somewhere else?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm just going to check--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's my mother's funeral tomorrow and the urn is in the suitcase.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm very sorry but let's check on this immediately.  This is definitely an emergency.  It seems--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I going to do tomorrow without the urn?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir it seems to me that your luggage is um- is not here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, that's a good deduction.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes--it is

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sherlock Holmes.  God, where's my luggage?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, Please please, I would ask you to just calm down for a second--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm down?  It's my mother's funeral tomorrow.  I'm the one responsible for this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  We will find your luggage.  Apparently because it somehow...what flight you were taking, you were on Delta?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  You are a Delta representative.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What is the matter with you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, I just...you need to calm down is what needs to happen right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't yell at me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm not.  I'm sorry, I am being--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: calm.  Sir, okay basically what- what's going to happen here is you're going to give me your contact information and we will contact you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God.  I think a blood vessel burst in my head.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Please, please

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: sir, listen to me.  Your luggage is still in Baltimore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  We can get it here in about seven to ten business days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  Well, because--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give- Give me your manager right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am the manager sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're the manager? You don't know where you work for, you don't know where you're at and you're the manager?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir I know where I work for but I was checking because you cannot--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whose daughter are you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sir. Sir. Sir. Sir

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is your name?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My name is Brent Caption.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now what are you going to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's it going, babe?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey listen,eh- I've been wanting to talk to you. I have something to tell you. How's Amy doing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's doing fine. She just took her first steps today actually. I videotaped it for you so you can watch it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I really want to say that. Well I, so, you know, at the center department they called me in and I talked to-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah? What did they say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well umm- actually they--I was promoted.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, wow. That's great.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And Uh- Yeah. Uh- They're going to need um- more nurses on call for uh- to go overseas to help out with the war.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And uh - seeing as I was uh- promoted and head of the department now, and so- well, they asked me to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: when?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going- It's going to be probably in about three weeks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? You can't do that. Three weeks?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm leaving in three weeks, but-- Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, we're supposed to take a look at a house next week.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we can still do that

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't- No, I can't do this alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and uh--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amy's starting school in a month.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, but look, I have to take this. I mean, if I don't, I mean, I could get fired.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And we know you need-we need the money. We couldn't even- purchase a house if I didn't take this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what happened to my cousin. She went and she never came back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey, I'm going to come back. It's not like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But it- it is for a year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Babe, I'm sorry. But I don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know as much as -as much as me that I-I want to stay here with you and Amy so bad, but I can't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember the last time you went? You know how hard it was for me? Now we have a kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But you're so good with her. You know, she knows you better than she knows me 'cause I'm at work every day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Babe, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't leave your daughter alone like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But she has you. I mean, that's what you're there for. You're my right-hand man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't postpone it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Wait, you can write me and as you know, send me pictures.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if I can handle you going another year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if I- if I could take it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I need you to be strong for me. 'Cause I can't be the only one that's strong right now, really, I--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't be that strong. A whole year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: me, oh my god.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But we can work, you know, we--you can write me and we could see pictures

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What if you don't come back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and if we survive, if we survive that then babe, you know you know we could survive any--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will come back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I supposed--oh, one out of five people aren't coming back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It doesn't look very good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can do it. I'm going to do it. And I'll be back safe and sound and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: we'll have all the money that we ever needed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And- And then I'll stop working and- I'll stay home with the baby.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want the money. I want-you here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: we'll get money, all right? You don't need the job, all right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If your life is going to be in danger and this family is going to be in danger we don't need the job. We'll find the money.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's all I ever knew how to do. I can't quit now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How are we supposed to tell Amy? How's she supposed to understand that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, we- we tell her mommy's going on va- on a trip for for- a while.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How is she going to feel the first year in school, no mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't do that to me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's hard enough already, Brian, I can't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not thinking about just me; I'm thinking about our child.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't expect this to happen. I never planned for this. Some things you just don't plan for, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, babe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look sir, I've been waiting for about an hour and my luggage still hasn't come. What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Rosenkrantz, but uh- I don't know what to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, you don't know what to tell me? I have two luggage that I've been coming--they're coming--from France and I need them here. I'm home now. I need to go start working.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you- Did you check with the lost and found?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where? I don't know. The lost and found. What do you mean, lost and found?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I had my luggage transferred here from Paris to L.A. and now I'm here and I need to be working and I have all my stuff in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe it got lost. Did you think about that, mom?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's what I'm asking you. What--I don't know what happened to it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, not--we didn't lose it; maybe the airport lost it. Maybe someone stole it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Wait, sir. You're- You're completely not--what do you mean, stole it? How can they just steal it from an airplane? It was up in the air?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I mean, maybe in the little--going around thingy thing where bopper stole it from there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. All I know is that I am supposed to have my language here right now. Right now. And it's not there. And you're supposed to help me because you work at the airport. So give me my luggage or tell me where the hell it is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. What can we do is we can get your name and information and if it shows up we can send it to you so-- Wherever you stay

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, if it shows up? No, I need it now. I have my keys, I have my wallet, I have my money. I have thousands and thousands of dollars worth of stuff in there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not to mention I have my work in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'll have you fill out some paperwork and see if you can get started on something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what if- what if it is lost? Well, what are you guys going to do for me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, we'll file a complaint and we could possibly, you know, replace some of the things. I think-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and when you sign your ticket we could replace about fifteen percent of what's in the bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fifteen percent?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Up to a limit of twenty five dollars.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What? There- There's hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stuff in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whoa, maybe you should uh- have thought of a better way to send it than just in a bag, hmm? Did you think about that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no. You don't understand. This is--these are my belongings in the luggage. And I went to Paris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, why are you laughing at me? This isn't funny.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think that's kind of stupid, that you put a hundred thousands of dollars in the bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm sorry, if I--no, it's not stupid. You are supposed to have my luggage.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you lock- Did you lock it even? You probably didn't even lock it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, they said I couldn't lock it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER], That's what they say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give me--I'm going to talk to your supervisor. Give me your supervisor. I want to talk to your supervisor right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, let me get him.Oh, guess who the supervisor is? It's me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, do you have questions?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, get- I want the C.E.O. then.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello.  This is Viacom Services.  How can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hello?  God finally somebody, look, this is ridiculous.  I've been waiting online for like a half an hour now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry ma'am, what can I help you with?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look my, my phone isn't working.  I don't understand what's going on.  I am trying to call out.  I'm not receiving any calls

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and I need assistance with my...not only is my work phone, it's my home phone and look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: this is my business.  This is how I make money is through my phone.  It needs to be working.  Can you please help me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Can you give me the last four digits of your social security number so I can verify who I'm speaking with?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: two two six six.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  And your name is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Olivia.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Olivia. Um. Okay.  So how long has this problem been?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This has been going on for the past two weeks.  I called every single day.  Nobody is helping me.  You guys tell me the same thing over and over, call again, call again, call again--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what exactly is the problem?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't, I don't know what the problem is.  That's what I want you guys to...why is my service not turned on?  And I paid my bills on time.  I don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- I think part of it has to do with the network being down.  It's been having some trouble the last few weeks--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Well that is, that is fine and all.  I don't care.  I really don't care because I want my phone to work that's all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is I am paying you guys for service and I'm not getting any service.  I get, I get just dropped calls all the time and now it's completely not working at all.  I can't even call out, nine one one probably wouldn't even work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I understand--we're not-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Okay.  We're not charging you for any of these months.  We're going to give you three months free.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you better.  You better give me a whole freaking new phone that's what you better do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can give you a new phone--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want a camera phone actually.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can do that.  We can do that.  You just have to sign a one-year contract though with the--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no...  I'm done with these contract business because this is what can happen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You sign the contract and then down the line the phone doesn't work and you're stuck, you can't go to a new...no.  No contracts for me.  You give me a new phone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Besides, it's sort of out of hands at the moment----The whole electrical power outage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want to talk to a supervisor

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would like to talk to your supervisor.  Obviously you're incompetent and don't understand what I'm asking.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- Let me connect you to my supervisor.  Actually, he's out right now so I'm supervisor until he comes back. Um-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you could----speak with me some more, you could call back later on maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's ridiculous.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want to call back, you put me on hold for like hours and hours----and it's money, money, money, money and out of my pocket, out of my pocket--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't put you on hold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are a lot of people calling us having problems.  Every phone company is having the same problems ma'am

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every phone...every single phone company?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm hmmm.  Mmm hmmm.  The power outages, everything, hurricane Katrina. Everything's really messed up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is ridiculous.Well what are we supposed to do?  We starve then because I can't use my phone cause

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am a realtor and this is my business.  People are calling me all the time but you know, and I don't have a land line.  I can't afford to have a land line

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: don't you-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm really sorry ma'am.  There's not----a lot we can do for it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That you better be sorry.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you're not helping me at all.  God this is so frustrating.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I can do for you, if you want to make a call right now I could contact you through our computer.  I can call through my phone and you can speak through me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  No.  That's way too complicated.  Look--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you need to fix my phone.  I don't care what you have to do--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry it has to do with an electrical power outage and stuff--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then go up the freaking pole and fix it like, you need to help me.  You don't understand I'm in dire, dire need of a phone right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, okay I'm going to give you a free phone card that you can use at any payphone and that's on us. Okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah yeah, woman going out in South Central on the payphone at night.  Oh that's real safe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm, I'm sorry you chose to live there um--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no.  I didn't choose to live here.  I work there.  Okay?  Yeah. work work work

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I'm sure maybe there's a phone at work you could use.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can't call out.  We can't make out-- line.  I don't work, I work at another office.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A law firm.  Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right um--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I work out of my home as a realtor and because I don't have a land line, I need a phone and because of now I don't have one I don't know what to do.  And you're not helping me at all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In fact, give me your name sir, what's your name again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My name is Sara.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Sara what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sara Brown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sara Brown.  Sara Brown, um- yeah, I'm going to get off the phone with you. And then I'm going to call back and I'm going to give your supervisor your name because you're obviously incompetent to work here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know maam, we record this conversation so anything you say can be proven in a law of court so keep that in mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you, what are you a police officer now?  You know, like I'm done, I'm over it.  Goodbye and I hope that you lose your job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know it went out of style didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.  It's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not sorry, no but I'm not staying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You saw that and you- you've been kind of-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so but they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would, your mother anyway.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From her point of view why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wouldn't you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have no imagination that's all I know to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you.  I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: wanted some place we'd never been, a place where we'd be brand new to each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is wrong, this chair, this yard.  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever.  You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  Till then you never wrote and then when you did what did you say.  I mean you sure can be ambiguous you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Ann.  Give me a-God I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it Chris?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive some place.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  What is it Chris, your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then what's wrong?  Even in your letters there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I suppose I have been but it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's so many things mixed up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, gees.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a lot of time to toss that off because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I put them in my pocket. that's only a little thing but these are the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I got this idea watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed see, but it seemed to me that there was one new thing that was made

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: a sort of responsibility man for man.  You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then I came home and it was amazing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There was no meaning in it here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The whole thing to them was sort of a bus accident. Then I went to work with father and that whole rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: because nobody was changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I felt wrong to be alive, to open the new bank book, to drive the new car, to see the new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean you can take those things out of war but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've got to be a little better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise what you have is really just loot and there's blood on it.  I didn't want to take any of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right but you don't think like that because what the hell is this all for.  This is all for you, what are we working for Chris? The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one who still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It kind of went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not so bad; it's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You know, it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not sorry, no. But I'm...I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For one thing, your mother much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And then, you.  You've been kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sort of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I was kind of planning of sneaking up on you over the course of a week or so.  They just take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure, from your mother's point of view.  Why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So would you want to?  I mean, I guess you have to know that's kind of why I asked you to come?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I, umm. I guess, I guess that's kind of why I came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you. Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't really have any imagination, that's all I know how to say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Am I embarrassing you? Are you - See, I didn't want to do it here with this yard, on this porch.  I wanted it to be somewhere new, some place fresh for both of us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel uncomfortable here, you feel that it's wrong here somehow.  I just...I don't...I didn't want...I didn't want to take you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long, time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever?  Are you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.  And when you did finally write me,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie, we are going to live now.  I am going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, let's drive some place.  Huh?  Let's get out of here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's nothing like that. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what?  Chris.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I suppose I have been. But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't even know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just all mixed up with so many other things, you know?  You know overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty much all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't just toss off a thing like that because they weren't just men. You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.  He just put them in my pocket.  That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that, exactly.  Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I had this idea as I was watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed, you know, but this one thing was being made.  It was kind of a monument, it's kind of responsibility, man for man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But then I came home and it was incredible, you know?  The whole thing was just kind of this random bus accident.  You know, I went back to the rat race again, I went to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Driving my new car and seeing a new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way.  Everything you have, you've earned - everything.  you understand me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even me.  And your money?  Chris, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes into the air, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie.  I am going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What would I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at this, all of the hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I was saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think it's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR! Somebody sold you a bunch of crap that there is this wonderful thing that is going to happen tonight on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Not just me, look at all of these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Everybody's told the same story.  It keeps us coming back for more, it keeps us excited.  We keep thinking that life is going start at any minute if we can just find the right spot, get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing, here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, it's just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Now, don't take this the wrong way, but are you on your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that, you always ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then, what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas of what this night is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There is nothing to it; we come down here, the fish arrive, they flop around, they do their fish thing.  We go ooh, ah, look at the fish and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God- Grow up, Augie.  The fish are not going to arrive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because they never do.  Have they...Have they ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we have tried; that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They'll show up this time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No they won't.  It's like waiting for Santa Claus.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like my whole life is going to be spent standing on this beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for fish to show up.  And the fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I am saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. Of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it, I still do, I always do.  I just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm always just standing here waiting.  I feel like this night is going to be the night, but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish, it's nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm trying to work this backwards and pinpoint the exact moment where we took a turn for the worst here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So you were fine during that phone call from Marge and then dinner was okay.  And doing the dishes was fine and then I was going to take a shower and you're watching the news and you said the grunions are running tonight, do you want to go?  And I said, sure great, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So I am putting out the pets, getting the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first year we came here?  It was like four years after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant, we got a bottle of champagne, we had no glasses.  We took off our shoes and you asked me to dance.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You whispered the sweetest, most intimate things to me right into my ear so I could feel them as much as hear them.  And I remember thinking, this is it.  You know, finally, I am as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Drinking champagne from the bottle,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's when we were driving past that Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said, let's get some champagne.  I said no, time's a wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: dancing barefoot in the sand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's what it is?  Right?  You want this to be like the other time, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember some things.  I'd rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure.  All right.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to go get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to take off your shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no. Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  What?  Do you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like a new carpet?  A poodle?  A back rub?  Ice cream?  A suicide pact?  What do you want?  What the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just want something to turn out like I expected it to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race, huh?  Do you think I had some grand fantasy going that four years down the line we would come to this beach and be arguing over fish?  No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I'm just like you.  I thought it was going to be all roses and peaches and the bills would just pay themselves.  And we'll have three, fat rosy cheeked children.  Huh, baby, the joke's on us.  Because you know what you get?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you know what you get?  You get this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This? What is this?  This is nothing.  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure.  This is standing on the beach waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean this is a lot of things, but it's just...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you understand what I am saying?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are Augie, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you meant this to be special, I know that you wanted it to be right, but I just can't help thinking that, I can't help wishing that I was somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with someone else, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just- I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be ridiculous.  Anything that- anything I am doing, I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For Heaven's sake Augie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the one who probably wishes he was with somebody else.  Somebody who doesn't take things so seriously, who could enjoy herself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, actually now that you mention it, no I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So maybe we are in the wrong spot, but we are with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it seemed like such a good spot to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We have a great view of the moon from here, though, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  I noticed that, it's pretty. Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And look what I got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you bought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to go home?  Are you cold?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm beginning to think this might be the right spot after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.  If we're very quiet, the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and an half years, why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe...maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  You know he lived next door to the girl his whole life, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She is not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men, why is she still single?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my darkest moments, I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey look, it's a nice day, huh?  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith, Joe.  You know strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to-- I want you to act like he is coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since Chris invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  Oh laugh, laugh all you like but why does this happen the very night he comes back.  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just believe with me, Joe. Only last week a man came back in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  Believe with me. You, above all, have got to believe. Just believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You seem kind of down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's--I've been trying to find this job I can't get any job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean I've been looking for a job for like three years and I can't get a job.  I mean like, it's America, right?  I should be able to get a job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's a lot of people looking for jobs.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess.  But three years?  I mean, I like--I went to college even, I mean I didn't finish but I went for like a little bit.  It's not fair, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, I mean, I just don't think...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean I've been sending out my resumes and doing everything I can do but nothing is happening.  You know, it's like I can't and I can't keep living on loans anymore like this.  I'm going to--I mean eventually I'm going to have to pay it back. I'm just kind of freaking out, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ever think it might be your attitude that's...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's my--like what do you mean "my attitude"?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know just sometimes you get kind of... No, I'm not saying that.  I just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do I have an attitude problem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, well maybe it's because I'm like frustrated 'cause I can't get a job, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...has anyone ever just said anything like that to you before?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like it's really hard to like shake that off when you go into like audition a room or whatever, you know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right, sure.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But I mean you kind of got to, you got to fake it 'til you feel it, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess I just getting really hard to fake, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying that if I was looking to hire somebody in the--or kind of... No. No. No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you hiring? Wait, do you know of a job? Seriously, do you know, like do you know of anything though?  Like, oh please, do you know of anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm just saying though that if I was a person who was hiring somebody I-- --would not hire someone who was angry or upset.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I come across angry?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you know a little.  If you were to listen to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  You're my friend you can tell me stuff.  You can tell me honestly stuff, okay?  Please.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't want you to fly off the handle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, I'm not flying off the handle I don't think I'm flying off the handle here at all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You kind of have a short fuse.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have a short fuse?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Okay no, no, no, no okay no, I need to hear this more. Come on, bring it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like this, right now we're trying have a conversation.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We're trying to have a conversation and you seem extremely hostile. You keep cutting me off.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, it's 'cause I can't get a job, okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not always right I'm just--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't finish the sentence with you without you jumping in...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and you're always right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: fine okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have an excuse for everything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying that maybe you should take in some information before you produce more of your own.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm like a sponge I'm like soaked up with all this information for like three years I'm just dying for a job to like put it in to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's -.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what kind of field are you looking to go into?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's it.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm--every lead that I get ends up just being a dead end.  You know what I mean.  People are sick of me calling--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You can't think that way.  I mean it's good--it's good that you're--that you're calling, you know. you can't

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, we're not hiring at this time or thank you, we already have your information on file--We'll call you when we're ready.

dialogue.text: But, it's been so long, like--I mine as well just take a job at McDonald's.  Like, I don't--

dialogue.text: No, come on.  Don't [GARBAGE]

dialogue.text: I just--I can't do it anymore.  Like, it just takes it out of you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I know. It's hard, but you just--you gotta keep going.  I mean, you've been going at it for so long, you know.  Something is definitely going to come up.  I-I know it will, because you're a good worker--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just keep getting rejected.  I just keep getting rejected over and over and over again and it starts to make you feel like there must be something wrong with you that you can't get a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  It's--I mean, it's competitive, you know.  That's-That's what it is.  that's what you gotta be is competitive.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but maybe--if just because it's competitive, like maybe I'm just not good enough.  Maybe the level is here and I'm here and there's just no way I'm ever gonna do that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There...There are plenty of people out there with--with like, good jobs, you know, that are a lot...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...dumber than you.  I mean they're a lot worse off than you.  You are much better off than like a lot of those people in there. I know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't have like one of those starts, you know, like a family member who was already in the business or something you know that could like give me a helping hand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It makes it harder.  I mean it's definitely who you know in a lot of cases, but--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's just so frustrating.  Like, I just--I just don't wanna do it anymore.  You know?  I just don't wanna like hit the pavement every single day with my resumes and going out there all the time.  You know, it's just like--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But you gotta.  Otherwise, what is--what's your other option?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel so worthless.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not worthless 'cause it's definitely gonna--it's definitely gonna pay off.  I know it.  I mean, I can--I've just--I've seen your work etiquette.  You know, you're a good worker and...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ... and there's no reason that--that something won't come up like really soon.  All right?  So you just gotta--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what would make you say that?  There doesn't seem to be any indicators that anything's going to get better.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because I know you.  You know, and maybe once you get to know some more people, like talking to them and everything, they'll get to know you too and they'll realize they should've hired you three years ago.  You know? but  And- and they'll finally come around and believe me--it'll--you gotta-

dialogue.text: It's just really hard.  I feel like their starting to get like a personal prejudice against me.  You know what I mean?  Like it's like suddenly it starts to feel like it's just you that they say no to and it's not that they're not taking applications and it's not that they're not hiring people, it's just you particularly they have some particular reason for just hating you.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe yeah, but maybe you get to that point where it's like you bug 'em and then they just don't wanna hear from you anymore, but you keep bugging them and bugging them and then it's gonna annoy them so much that they're gonna be like all right fine. you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or they'll never talk to me again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or, well, no.  Okay. you -[GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I-I just I think maybe I should try something else.  I mean, I-I don't know.  All growing up this is the only thing that I ever wanted to do and yet I can't.  I'm not physically able apparently.  I mean--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That obviously that's not true though.  I mean, you've done this before.  You've done all the work like this before, you know, and and you've gotten people saying oh, you're so good and like you know--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess the money shouldn't matter to me, but--Somehow it does.  You know? It's not like I do it for the money, but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you've gotta live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you have to--I mean, if you're hired by somebody, then you're not a professional, you're an amateur and that means that you're not good enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, it's just, it's really--I don't know, yeah, it's about their opinions and it's about, I don't know, just getting yourself out there and--

dialogue.text: I just wanna crawl in a hole, you know.  Like it just makes you not wanna even open your eyes in the morning.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, come on, come on.  Thinking about it like this is definitely not gonna help either though.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know how to get out of it.  I don't know how to dig myself out of it.  It's the same hole that I've been digging and digging and digging.  I can't--

dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up, he was still in bed.

dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  When it cracked, he ran back in the house and cried in the kitchen.
