dialogue.text: What are you getting so excited about?  I mean, it's not like it's like the landing on the moon or something.  I mean, it's just fish, fish that nobody eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  But it's fish that do something that no other fish do.  Like the swallows in Capistrano or the Lemmings that throw themselves off the cliffs, there's magic here and some mystery and a little bit of unexplainable.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, I can't see how you can not be interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't get it.  I mean the first time we came to see it, you said it was the best night of your life.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year when we came you ran out of the house so fast you stubbed your toe and you didn't even notice it until we got in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You also could remember that I got sand in my panties, we got in an argument over nothing, you got a sore throat and we didn't even get to see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  We're in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You didn't see them the first time either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in the good spot.  This is a much better spot.  You know, I have a good instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, is that...no is that just seaweed?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, this is great isn't it?  You know, I wouldn't trade this for anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, think about this, I know you're not interested but just think about this for a minute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Somewhere out there, there's this huge silver mass of fish heading this way, they don't why, we don't know why, they just some little instinctual fire cracker went off in their bodies...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...like and they all just turned at once and formed a line as long as the California coast and started swimming this way.  They didn't, you know, they didn't make a decision, they didn't, you know, have boats or anything.  No one sent them an invitation or a map, they just started swimming as if that's the only thing that matters.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It's urgency that's pure urge and they don't, they don't ask it a question, they don't give it a name, they just swim.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They just start swimming to this place right here where we stand for massive celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm giving myself goose bumps.  Look, all my hairs are standing up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I just said?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, nobody knows we're here except for Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are we to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right, aren't we darling? Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello? What? Ugh, wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] God, it sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: things that should matter dreadfully don't seem to matter at all when one's happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um terrible thing is one can't stay happy. Well, it's true. I mean, the whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mean that sacred and beautiful thing, love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean? That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth. What does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me. I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. You mustn't be serious, my dear one, that's what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable. Laugh at them. Be flippant. Laugh at all the sacred shibboleths. Flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if I laugh at everything I'm going to have to laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh, certainly you must. We're figures of fun, all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So how long is it going to last? This ludicrous, overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. The fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, well, shall we want that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we play it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what if happens if one of us is to die? Does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. Yes, he must with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's serious enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No, it isn't. Death's very laughable. A cunning little mystery. All done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run. Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's blow strumpets, blow-blow trumpets and squeakers and party as much as we can like small quite idiotic school children. Let's savor the delight of the moment. Come, kiss me darling, before worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do, see? As long-you can paint yourself bright green all over and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you, dear. The same applies to you. Except that if I ever so much as catch you looking at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles. That was his name. Charles. He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible little thing. I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did. You threw it out the window and into the Grand Canal. I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your-your curling iron burnt a hole in my dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I burnt a hole in my comb too, and all the towels in the bathroom. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah. And that was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling on the floor and biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. Oh man. Couldn't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I will never forget his face. Ooh-rah [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?  Maybe we ought to talk to him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean. He couldn't have seen it. I was the first one up, he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four in the morning.  I heard a crack and I looked out and he was standing right there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what was he doing out at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. But after it cracked he ran back into the house and he cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured the best thing to do was leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear it right through the floor.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, what was he doing out there anyway?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Starting to dream about him again.  He's walking around at night again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like he did after he died, you know?  What, what, what's the meaning of this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I know one thing mom, we made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  That kind of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know that too.  Why we both go on letting him think that we both believe with him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you going to do?  You want to argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I don't want to argue with him but, it's time that he realizes that nobody believes Larry's coming back anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he walk around and dream at him at night.  Walk around.  Why shouldn't he walk around?  Why shouldn't he dream of him, walk around at night waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say flat out that we don't have anymore hope?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How are you going to prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Larry's been gone for three years.  For god sakes no one comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you maybe, to me, but not to your father.  I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he still thinks he's alive still.  I mean you could talk yourself blue in the face and there's no body and there's no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen mom, just, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  It's his god damned newspapers is what it is.  Now every month there's a new boy comes home and Larry's going to be the next one.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright. Alright. Alright just listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I have an idea but I don't know.  What's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's your business Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  I mean, you're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So then it's alright.  I'll go ahead with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, you got to make sure your dad's not going--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh see then it's just not my business. God you infuriate me sometimes.  Isn't my business too if dad throws a fit?  Huh?  God you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm just saying--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know I ignore what I got to ignore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not...she's Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view he is still alive and if you try and take her that's just not fair.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something I want I have to pull back

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And-And-And if you go on from there if you know already to go on from there, then you can.  But I'm telling you something that I don't know where to go.  You got it?  I mean, do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because other people will suffer.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My whole entire, bloody life time and time again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There is nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well to hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what if she doesn't marry you huh?  What if she feels the same way your father does?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I guess that's the end of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.  I'll find out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with dad right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, you never had seen many, many women.  You know?  I mean...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what?  I'm just not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's a good answer but, it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you left to go to the war and it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just...that's just the way it is.  That's how I feel.  You know these years when I think of someone I want to marry I think of Annie.  What do you want a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. And you go off and marry that girl and you're just pronouncing him dead and what's going to happen to him?  I don't know.  Do you?  I mean, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, just give it some thought okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought and I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll marry her somewhere else.  Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long.  A good sucker and I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're just going to leave the business?  You have a business here.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it an hour out of the day.  If I have to grub for money all day long at least at evening I want it beautiful.  I want a family.  I want a wife.  I want some kids.  I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now Annie is in the middle of all that.  Where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.  You can leave this business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you can't talk like that you hear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean what the hell have we worked for then?  I mean, it's all for you Chris.  The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Just you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you don't talk like that you hear?  You don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I said.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR.  Somebody sold you a bill of goods that this wonderful event is going to take place on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not the only one.  Look at these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure everybody's told the same story.  It keeps us all coming back for more.  It keeps us all excited, keeps us thinking that life is going to start any minute now if we can just find the right spot and get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm sorry but it's still just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Don't take this the wrong way but are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Goddamn it Augie don't ask me that.  You always ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas about what this evening is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  We come down here.  The grunions arrive.  They do their little fish business.  We go oh, ah look at the fish.  They go home.  We go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We totally skipped. Right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  We come down here.  The grunions arrive.  They do the little fish business.  We go oh, ah look at the fish.  They go home.  We go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, grow up we are not going to see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We never do.  Do we have we ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice that's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we've tried that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll see them this year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, we won't.  It's pointless.  It's like waiting up to see Santa Clause.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God I feel as though my entire life is going to be spent standing on the beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for the fish to show up,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and the fish won't show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I'm saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it.  I always do.  I keep thinking that this time will be the time but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just a fish.  Nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been trying to work this backwards but I can't seem to pinpoint the moment when we took a turn for the worse.  You were fine during the phone call from Marge.  Dinner was okay.  Doing the dishes was no problem.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's see I took a shower.  You watched the news.  You said the Grunions are running tonight. I said great let's go.  I feel lucky tonight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Uh, so I'm putting on my jacket, putting out the animals.  We're getting the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first time we came to see it?  It was about four years ago right after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant and we had a bottle of champagne but no glasses.  You asked me to dance.  So we took off our shoes

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and you popped the cork and while we were dancing, you said the softest most intimate things to me

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: right into my ear so that I could hear them as much as- so that I could feel them as much as hear them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I remember thinking this is it.  At last, at last I'm as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute.  I've got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dancing barefoot in the sand, drinking champagne from the bottle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was in the car right.  Driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said let's get some champagne and I said times a wasting or something like that.  Right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's it, right?  You want this to be like the other time, right.  That's it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would rather not remember some things.  I would rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Right.  I got it.  Sure.  Of course.  Listen you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want me to get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well what?  Want me to breath in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  What do you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A new carpet, a poodle, a backrub, ice cream, a suicide pact.  What?  What?  Carla what the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want something to turn out the way it's supposed to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race.  You think this is what I had in mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you think that when I proposed, I had this great fantasy going that four years down the line we'd come to the beach and yell at each other over fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you think that I knew that there'd be times when you'd look at me like I'm a used Kleenex and times I would look at you and think holy hell when's the next flight to Alaska.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: What are you gonna do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him.  But it's time that he knows that nobody else believes that Larry's alive. I mean

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he dream about him, walk the nights waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say outright that we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for a long time?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how are you gonna prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For Gods sake, three years!  Nobody comes back after three years.  It's insane!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: The trouble is the God damn newspapers, I mean, ea- each week a new boy turns up out of nowhere.  So the next one is gonna be Larry.  So you--

dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't gonna --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Isn't it your business, too, if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it?  You have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore.  I mean, the girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: As far as your father is concerned, he's not dead.  And she's still his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now, you can go on with this if you know where to go, but I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something that I want, I have to pull back because it might hurt somebody else, my whole bloody life, time after time, after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you're a considerate fella.  There's nothing wrong with that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: what to hell with that!

dialogue.text: Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she'll marry you?  Maybe she feels like your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [garbage] I don't know.  It's just,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: she's who I know best. I know her since I- I was a kid I grew up with her.  When I think of somebody for my wife these days, I I think of Annie.  What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want a-  Your father thinks he's coming back, Chris.  If you marry that girl, you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now, what's going to happen to your father, do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.text: All right then, mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But don't think like that because what the hell did we work for, Chris?  All of this, all of it, it's all just for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't think like that, do you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Good God.

dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: what, Nobody knows we are here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: What's so horrible is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being that sacred and wonderful thing, love.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Meaning just that.

dialogue.text: uh- the- Being flippant brings out the acid in their damned beauty and light.

dialogue.text: [garbage] who knows?

dialogue.text: Well, will we always bicker and fight?

dialogue.text: Well, it depends on how well we played.

dialogue.text: Right.

Actually, I wanted to go a little further up the coast you know to get away from all the lights and the people.  I was afraid we might miss it though, so how are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You keep saying my flashlight like it's just yours.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's that supposed to make me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, our flashlight.  What's yours is mine.  Me flashlight es su flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Naturally.  God, how could we not think to bring it?  I hope the moon stays out, though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do they always run during a full moon?  I don't remember.  Was it full last year?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh.  Are you cold?  Do you want my jacket?  No?  you know, we should have brought the blanket?  Our blanket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Aw.  Do you know, I should have brought a six pack, too.  A six pack, that would be just the ticket right about now.  Huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I'm so excited, I'm like a kid.  I can't believe I got out of the house with my fly zipped up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder if they can hear me talk or like feel the vibrations in the sand when we move around.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm cold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want my jacket?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's after eleven, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  We just got here.  What's the point of coming all the way down here if we just turn around and go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There is no point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's my point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait, that's my point, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, then let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no.  Okay.  That's not my point.  My point is there is no point in coming down here if we just turn around and go home.  Don't you want to see it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not particularly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't.  It's stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey, this is like a natural phenomenon. I mean... People in Kansas would have to get plane reservations and get hotel rooms to see this.  It's just forty minutes away for us; it's too good to pass up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pass what up?  I mean these fish swim out of the ocean, they flop around on the beach, they swim away and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But this..this moment on the beach is like the highlight of their little lives.  All that flopping around is laying eggs or what to do - spawning or mating or whatever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a big night for these little guys.  It's like life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you're so excited; this isn't a freaking moon landing we are talking about.  It's fish.  It's a fish nobody even eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Augie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay... well, Whatever.  But it's a fish who do something no other fish do.  It's like those swallows returning to Capistrano or like those lemmings that throw themselves off the cliffs.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's like mystery here, there's magic.  It's like a little bit of the unexplainable.  I just can't see how you're not interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I don't get it.  you know the first time we came here, you said it was the best night of your life?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year, I remember distinctly you said, you were so excited to get here that you don't remember you stubbed your toe until we were in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last time, you'll also remember, we got our shoes wet, I got sand in my panties, you got a sore throat and we got into a big fight and we did not see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ahh...we weren't in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  We didn't see them the year before either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot.  I'm telling you, this is a much better spot.  I have instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look there, see?  What's that?  No, that's - that's just seaweed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, this is great.  Think about this.  I know you are not interested, but just think about this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right now out there, there is this mass of silver fish and it's heading this way.  No one sent them an invitation, no one told them, no one even gave them a map.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just all at once, they turned and they formed this line as long as the California coast.  And some instinctual little firecracker went off in their bodies and they all just turned as one and started swimming.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They are swimming right now.  They are swimming as if that is the only thing that matters to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It is urgency that is just pure urge.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And they are swimming right now to this very point where we stand for this huge celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh look.  I'm giving myself goose bumps, my hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About all of that, about all I was talking about.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe he wanted see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's been three and a half years.  Why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well uh, He grew up next door to the girl, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, now listen, kids...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The girl is not Larry's.  If the girl is Larry's girl she's not his she know she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen. Line. You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men probably a hundred people told her she is crazy but she is waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And how do you know why she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know that's why.  She's faithful as a rock. in my darkest moments I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, look it's a beautiful day.  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith Joe.  Her- strangers might but not her father, not her brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?  What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to---act like he is coming back.  Don't think I haven't noticed you, both of you since Chris invited her here.  I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back then I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, laugh at me, laugh all you like but why does this happen to very night she comes back?  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me Joe, you got to believe. Only last week a boy came back missing longer then Larry you read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, calm yourself. Alright.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You above all have got to believe. Just don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean? Me above all? What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you. You're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What the hell do you want from me, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and an half years, why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe...maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  You know he lived next door to the girl his whole life, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She is not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men, why is she still single?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my darkest moments, I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey look, it's a nice day, huh?  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith, Joe.  You know strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to-- I want you to act like he is coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since Chris invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  Oh laugh, laugh all you like but why does this happen the very night he comes back.  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just believe with me, Joe. Only last week a man came back in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  Believe with me. You, above all, have got to believe. Just believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, nobody knows we're here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right darling, aren't we whatever happens?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello? What? Wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. It sends shivers down my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do we do if they suddenly walk in on us?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With the most perfect poise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I should probably to a court curtsey.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Things that ought to matter dreadfully don't matter at all when one's is happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's so horrible is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh darling don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true; the whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Meaning that sacred and beautiful thing love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean that's what I ask- that's what I ask myself in my ceaseless quest for ultimate truth?  Good God what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me. I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mustn't be serious my dear one, that's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All those futile moralists, who try to make life unbearable, laugh at them, be flippant. Laugh at everything all their sacred shibboleths

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: flippancy brings out the acid in their damned sweetness in light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if I laugh at everything then I must laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly you must, we figures of fun all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, that desire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, should we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we play it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what happens if one of us dies, does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no it isn't, death is very laughable, such a cunning little mystery, all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers, let's blow our trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party as much as we can. Like quite idiotic, very small, school children. Let's savor the delight of the moment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliot, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do see. You can paint yourself green and dance naked in the Place Vendome, and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word, as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you dear, the same applies you, except that if I catch you so much as looking at another woman, I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little, painted, wooden snake in the Piazza and put it on my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles, that was his name Charles. It did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible thing, I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did. You threw it out of the window into the Grand Canal; I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your curling iron burned a hole in my new dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It burned my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling around on the floor biting and scratching like panthers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll never forget his face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh it was ridiculous, completely ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he gonna say?  Maybe we ought to tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up, he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four this morning.  I heard it cracking and I woke up and looked out. He was standing right here when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  When it cracked, he ran back in the house and cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I thought it was best to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear him right through the floor of my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at that hour?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming about him again.  He's walking around at night.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like after he died.  What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But, I know one thing Mom, we made a terrible mistake with Dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  I mean, that sort of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I don't want to argue with him, but it's about time he realized that nobody believes Larry's alive anymore?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he dream of him and walk the nights waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can you prove it?  How can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God sakes, it's been three years.  Nobody comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.  I mean, you can talk yourself blue in the face, but he--there's no body and no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Trouble is the God damn newspapers.  Every month or so a boy turns up out of nowhere so, you know, the next one is gonna be Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right.  Listen to me.  You know why I brought Annie here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've got an idea, but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm gonna ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's all right then?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't going to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, then it isn't just my business--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, sometimes you infuriate me.  You know that?  I mean, isn't it your business too if I tell Dad and flips--freaks out about it?  I mean, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I gotta ignore.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he isn't dead.  And you've no right to take his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.  Now what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why, but, every time I reach out for something that I want, I have to pull back 'cause someone else will suffer.  My whole bloody life.  Time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong with that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she'll marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does, then that's the end of it.  But from her letters, I think she's forgotten him.  I'll find out.  And then we'll thrash it out with Dad, right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Trouble is, you don't see enough women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what, I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything.  I mean, you've been away for--at war.  It's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it.  I know her best.  I mean, I grew up next door to her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: These years when I think of a wife, I think of Annie.  What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.  Umm-- He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl and you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, what's gonna happen to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right, then, Mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just--give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  I thought that if I waited Dad would forget about Larry and we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't--if that can't happen here, then I'll have to get out.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] It's gotta be it, like-

dialogue.text: Oh my Gosh, that's so cool.

dialogue.text: Hey, yes, you know that's - that's what I'm coming for.

dialogue.text: Yay.

dialogue.text: Right I know, like you, it won't hurt, I mean national champions last year, wow, you know

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's that? ahh Well, you know I'm I'm thinking um I'm leaning towards like communications

dialogue.text: yeah, I mean a lot-a lot  of good stuff oh, yeah, I mean it's- it's just a really good school; so really, whatever I pick I can't go wrong. I mean I'm just

dialogue.text: Oh man. So, I don't know you know, we'll see - we'll see how it goes and, yeah, I'm looking forward to it

dialogue.text: Yay

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. Yes, totally come visit

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Thanks, yes, thanks, yes That'll be cool.

dialogue.text: So Congratulations. That's awesome.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: No of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heavens sake this isn't about fish.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: Wait a minute I've got it

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.text: Well, but this isn't anything like I thought anything would be like.

dialogue.text: She's not-

dialogue.text: It's got that all about it.

dialogue.text: Now, listen Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to act like he's coming back.  Both of you.  Don't you think I haven't noticed since she got here.  I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But Kate--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  I mean, laugh--laugh at me, but...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But why did that happen the very night she came here?  She sleeps in his room and his memorial breaks to pieces.  Just look.  Look at it.

dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.text: Last week, a man turned up in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  I mean, you read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right.  Calm yourself.

dialogue.text: You, above all, have to believe.

dialogue.text: What?- Why- Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just--just don't stop believing.

dialogue.text: What does that mean?  Me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you.  Look at you shaking.

dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kathy died last night.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my God. Oh my God, I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah, I mean, you know, it was a -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess we saw it coming and she lasted a lot - a lot longer than, uh, they expected but you know, I mean when it actually happens it's just a lot harder.

dialogue.text: It doesn't make any easier, yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, man. I'm so sorry.

dialogue.text: It's going to be so rough, I'm sorry.

dialogue.text: Yes. I mean, it's not as rough on me as it is on him but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, it's you know, we've spent so much time with them it's just really surreal, really weird that we're not going to be able to see her anymore and go

dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.text: Yes. Well, at least you have a lot of good memories.

dialogue.text: She was [garbage]

dialogue.text: She really cared about you, you know.

dialogue.text: Yes, I mean she cared about all of us. She was great

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so loving everybody you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And she was

dialogue.text: Gosh, I just hate I just hate to see her go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.text: We were all going take a trip to Europe you know.

dialogue.text: Even if you still do she'll- she'll be there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  [BREATHING] God.

dialogue.text: Are you going to be okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just -- I just don't get it, like there is just nothing you can do about it you know, it's like just out of your control and it

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: just makes it that much harder to deal 'cause as much as you want to, you know, make her better, see her not in any pain, it's like, just I don't know, just has a mind of its own.

dialogue.text: Oh God I finally got...you know how long I've been waiting on line?  You put on hold for like five hours.  Geez.

dialogue.text: I'm sorry ma'am.  What's the nature of your problem?  But first can I get you to tell me your first and last name?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know I just need to verify every time.  I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Olivia Brown.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright Ms. Brown what's the nature of your problem?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well my phone isn't working and it hasn't been working for the last five days.
