dialogue.text: Oh.  I'm sorry. Um- Did you drop it in water?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah you better be sorry.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I did not drop my phone in water.  I'm not five years old and just dropped my phone anywhere I see it.  Okay this is my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay?  And it [GARBAGE]. My business is failing because my phone isn't working and I don't have a land line and I really can't handle this right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- well it's probably easy.  Can you any more symptoms either you're not receiving calls----ok, you're not receiving calls, not getting calls.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: the symptoms- This [GARBAGE] a doctor's office. I'm not receiving calls...I can't receive- no, it's, it cuts me off--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is the phone turned on?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes the phone turns on.  No I mean I'm using it not turning on the phone.  Of course it turns on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, um- okay.  Your sim card is in- didn't fall out-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No- I don't have a sim card because it's Verizon and you guys don't use sim cards.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright.  Um- Well that could be the problem. cause--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you might have an older phone where we would use sim cards but probably not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay no.  Sir, this is the deal.  My phone isn't working and I don't care what the problem is but it needs to work.  That's why I'm paying you guys to fix it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  How about this we'll send you a brand new camera phone with palm pilot-- and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know even how to use that stuff it's too complicated.  I just want my flip phone to work----that's all I need

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So we'll send it- And we'll give you, how about a free year's service?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I am on the road all the time.  Do you understand how important?  I'm a woman, a single mother by herself working...what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Tell them my name.  My name is Brent Backersen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Brent Backersen, I am writing this down, Brent Backersen.  Alright.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Tell them my - my ID number is two one three five.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Tell them that.  You can go in, get a brand new phone, they'll hook you up with service even give you a free three months--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I, I, I don't want a contract. Okay. I don't want any contracts.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It will be free.  No contract okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?  No contract?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Go in there, yeah, go in there.  Tell them Brent Backersen sent you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want the best freaking camera phone there is though.  I want the really good kind--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: the top of the line camera phone, game boy, anything you want. For free. And palm pilot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And palm pilot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And charger and accessories and I want a cover that's pink.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They might only have orange.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: no

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  They can figure out pink for you.  So go in there and just tell them that and they'll hook you up with other goodies, stuff like that free service, no contract, no nothing.  Just for being a good customer

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and battling through with us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright. Well-  I guess - I guess that's okay but,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you better promise me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  You just tell them Brent Backersen sent you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright?  Great.  Have a nice evening.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know that still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I know. It went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's all right. There's nothing wrong in that, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's really lovely here. The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. I'm not sorry. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, for one thing, your mother so much has told me to go. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you've been acting kind of, well, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you've been embarrassed ever since I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I guess I have been. But it's going from me now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh look, um, well, the thing is, I was planning on, planning on sort of sneaking up on you over a week or so, and they-they take it for granted we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, they would. Especially your mom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, uh- would you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I, I guess that's why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: from her opinion, why else would I come here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you a great deal.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I love you. I have no imagination. That's all I know how to tell it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess that's why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you. I didn't want to tell you it here. I wanted to go somewhere that would be brand-new to each other. It feels wrong here, don't you? This yard and this chair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to win you from anybody. I want you to be ready for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been ready for a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever. You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was almost married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause you started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know, you didn't write until then and then when you did, what'd you say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always can be so ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. God, I kissed Annie. I kissed Annie. How long, how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know if I ever can forgive you for that. Why'd you wait so long? I sat in my room wondering if I was crazy for thinking about you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to live now. I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that, you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother. Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive somewhere. I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it? Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. Nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then tell me what's wrong. I mean, even in your letters there's something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I guess there is. I guess I was, but uh- it's going from me now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You should tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, Chris, it wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know when I went overseas. I said I was in command of a company.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a little while to toss that off. Because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time, it had to have been raining several days. There was this one kid, he came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks. Put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, that's-that's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had. They didn't just die. They killed themselves for each other. And I mean that exactly. A little more selfish and they'd still be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I, and I thought something watching them go down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Everything was being destroyed, see, but there was one new thing that was being created. A kind of responsibility, man for man. You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And to show that-to bring that onto the earth like some sort of monument standing right behind us where everyone could feel it and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I came back here and it was incredible. There was no meaning in that here. The whole thing to them was a bus accident.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I went to work with dad and that rat race again. And I felt what you said-ashamed somehow. Because nobody was changed at all. It seemed to make a sucker out of a lot of guys.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt wrong to be alive. To drive the car, to see the new checkbook, to see the new refrigerator. I mean, you can take those things out of the war. But you got to know that when you drive that car that that came out of the love a man can have for another man. And you got to be a little bit better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise, what you have here is loot; and there's blood on it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want to take any of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you can't feel that way, never again, Chris. You hear me? Never. I mean, the money and me too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, there's nothing wrong in that money, and your father put good planes up in the air and you should be proud of that. A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, I'm going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What am I going to do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents? It was only a small trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I remember it well. Bristling with diamonds. In the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all. It was very pretty. And I wear it all the time. I still have it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I didn't. You made that up all in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit that he was in love with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, but it was nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you. You said so.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh come on, it gave him a lot of pleasure and it didn't harm me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you'd have never known anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's true.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you bored with this conversation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I definitely, most definitely am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I. Bored stiff. Want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want it; you've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason. Anyhow, they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see what's the point of going on and on about something like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my-you can hardly call three minute liquor glasses in the evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want some yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. Just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a woman's job to allure the man. Watch me, won't you, a minute?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's not. I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have more brandy. It might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it didn't seem to do such wonders with you, now did it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, they do. They have a big bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. I don't care, do you understand? I don't care if they bark, if they roll over on the floor like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uhh,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did, quite a lot actually.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine that you let him kiss you quite a bit more then, didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You had a riotous-must have had a riotous time. No restraint at all. Very enjoyable. You never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are quite insufferable. I suppose it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. As I mentioned before, I said I had three very minute liquor glasses. That's hardly enough to get a child of two drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two can get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very interesting indeed. How about a child of four or a child of six or a child of nine. We might have a splendid little debate about this intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want to talk about this anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's very late and it will annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs. It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I suppose the people downstairs then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had far too temperamental for yourself. You should try to control it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will not. Go away. Go away. I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very amusing, indeed. Amanda, listen-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen, indeed. No, no, no, no. I am sick and tired of listening to you, you sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it, stop it, I hate you, I loath you, you are overbearing and conceited and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, you're a vile, ill-tempered, wicked little beast and I hope that I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end. Do you hear? The end. Now and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you're not going out like this. No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I am. Let go of me. I hate you and I loath you. God, I can't believe I just finally realized how you are. I am never marry you. Never. Never, never, never. I would rather die in torment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up. Shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you again if you came back crawling to me on your hands and knees because you're vile. You're a mean, evil-minded little vampire and I hope to God I never set eyes on you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Beast or brute cad, swine beast beast brute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Wow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all going to miss him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmm hmm. I never knew it was going to be this hard, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird 'cause it's like you expected it to happen and eventually-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he had cancer, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm, Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They thought he got--would get better and he did, and then it just- things turned bad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turned around for the worst, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't know him, Tricia, but uh- I heard that he was a great man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was amazing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I loved that boy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We did everything together, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird, I think. I feel so alone, you know? What am I going to do now? Now that he's gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's so young. It seems so--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: so wrong in so many ways.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: His poor parents. You know, it's their only son.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Kind of a whole year. I mean, he suffered with this, this monster, this thing, this disease.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was in chemo the whole time, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he just got that baseball scholarship.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. He was, he had so much going for him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So handsome, so young, so gifted.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So talented.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Such a sweet person, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How's his parents doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can you imagine, though, you know, as a parent, just losing a kid? Twenty-two years old.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird, I kind of feel like part of me is gone now, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because this other half was just kind of like ripped away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You guys were pretty close, weren't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was like, he was like my brother, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was my brother.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just seems so unfair, is the way it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, he had that really pretty girlfriend for like about a year and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What was her name?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Kelly. Kelly Uveny.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kelly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They talked about getting married and--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Trying to have a baby.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. But then when he got cancer and it got bad, you know, she just took off and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: so I was there for him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Some people.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, but you were there all the hospital days. By his bed-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. God, I loved that kid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So nice, so positive.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We need more people like him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Joe, do you think he knew I loved him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I never told him, I love you, but-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I loved him so much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if Benny was smart like that- but-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sure he loved you too. He just didn't know it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  The real cause of that rile was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, come on, you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  A trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm Hmm.  I remember it well.  Bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all.  It was very pretty.  I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I didn't.  You made up the whole thing in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit he was in love with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps but nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you. You said so.  What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it didn't harm him, in fact, it pleasured him a lot and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you would've never known anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, that's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, so am I.  Bored stiff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know why you want it.  You've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see what you have to go on and on with this kind of thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my...just because I just...okay...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...having three small minute liquor glasses in the evening is hardly going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, just making myself beautiful for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the woman's job to lure the man.  Watch me a moment won't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think you should have some more brandy...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think that

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...cause really

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it doesn't seem to be working on you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: perhaps maybe you should've had more brandy, it might've made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it really hasn't worked wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm, snap, snap, snap like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes they do.  They have a bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care.  I don't care.  Do you understand?  I don't care if they roll around and bark like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did.  Quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you let him kiss you a great deal more then?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm, you must've had a riotous time.  No restraint at all, very enjoyable.  You never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable.  I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, like I mentioned before I had three very small, minute liquor glasses of brandy.  That's not even enough to get a child of two drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two can get violently drunk off just one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, what an interesting topic.  What about a child of four and a child of six?  A child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We might be able to bring up a splendid little debate about this intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny dear.  In fact, maybe you better have some more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, thanks.  I think I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because people upstairs will get annoyed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs.  This is a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well there are people downstairs I suppose.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They are away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, this is no time to be in here for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I'll do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well.  If you insist on being a boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come on, turn it off.  It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental.  Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it--Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Go away.  Go away.  I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I hate you.  Listen I'm sick and tired of listening to you, you sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what?  You're a vile, little, evil-minded, little, wicked beast and I never want to see you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end.  Understand?  This is the end, here and now, forever and always.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going nowhere. No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yes I am. Yes I am and you can't stop me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: shut up. shut up.  I would-I would never marry you again if you came crawling back to me on your hands and knees because you're an evil-minded little vampire and I hope to God I never see you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen, you're a cruel fiend and I hate, loathe you.  Thank God finally, finally thank God I've realized just how horrible you are--and marry you?  Marry you?  Never. I will never marry you.  I will die die in torment-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Beast. Brute. Cad. Swine. Beast. Beast. Brute. Devil. Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I just said?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's a slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR.  I mean, somebody sold you a good bill about this wonderful event that going to happen on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not the only one.  Look at all these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Everyone else was sold the same thing.  I mean, look, it keeps us excited, it keeps us coming back for more and you know, keeps us thinking life's going to start any minute now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I'm sorry but it's still just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, we just have different ideas of what this night is supposed to be like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  The Grunions arrive, they do their little fish business, you know?  We go oh, ahh, look at the fish and they go home and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heavens sake, grow up.  We're not going to see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We never do, do we?  Have we ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my gosh.  We missed them twice, that's hardly ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Twice is as many times as we've tried and that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't take this wrong but, are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, god dammit, don't ask me that.  You always ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's bugging you then?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, it's pointless.  It's...we're not going to see the Grunions I mean, it's like waiting around to see Santa Claus, you know, it's...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen, I've waiting my entire life on this beach just standing there waiting for this fish to show up and these fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, you don't understand anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I do.  I always do.  I keep thinking, this time will be the time and it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, we're going to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No we won't.  I mean, God, this isn't about the fish Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What...I've been trying to, I've been trying to figure out the point where we went wrong and I can't seem to pinpoint that moment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You were fine during the phone call with Marge, dinner was okay, doing the dishes was no problem.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's see I took a shower, you were watching the news, you said hey, hey the Grunions are running tonight and I said great let's go, I feel lucky tonight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then I'm putting the animals out in the yard, I'm pulling the car out of the garage, putting my jacket on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, do you remember the first time we came here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We brought a bottle of champagne and we took off our shoes and danced barefoot in the sand...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Under the moon and you whispered so softly into my ear so I could feel your words.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I thought, this is it.  This is how happy I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute.  I've got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  Dancing barefoot in the sand?  Drinking out of a bottle of champagne?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was in the car right?  Driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And you said let's get some champagne and I said time's a wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want this to be like the other time right?  That's it right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember something...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Rather not hope for something.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, right.  I got it.  Sure.  Of course.  Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  Do you want me to breathe in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again? What? What?  Do you want a divorce? A vacation? What?  A carpet?  A poodle?  A basket of fruit?  What?  A suicide pact?  What the hell do you want Carla?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No...No...No...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want things to turn out the way that they're supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Welcome to the human race.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you think that this is what I had in mind?  That four years down the line that we'd get married and come to the beach and argue with each other over fish?  No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was just like you.  I thought it was going to be all peaches and roses and everything great and the sand in our toes and the wind in our hair and the fish will always come and the bills will pay themselves and we'd have three big fat rosy kids...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...and you know?  Baby the jokes on us.  Because you know what you get?  Do you know what you get Carla?  You get this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This what...what's this?  This isn't anything. Alright.  Sure.  Standing on the beach, fighting and waiting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cause everything isn't anything like I thought it would be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I know.  Me neither.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is just this.  You know?  I mean it's a lot and everything but it isn't somewhere else.  Do you know what I'm trying to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm trying to do the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are Augie.  I know you wanted this evening to be nice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help thinking about being somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with someone else too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  But I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, whatever I'm doing I'd rather be doing with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If anybody wants to be with anybody else it's probably you.  Probably somebody who enjoys herself a little more and is not so hard.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually, now that you mention it, no I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess this is the wrong spot for the right people.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It seemed like a good spot to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean look at the view of the moon we got from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I noticed that.  It's real pretty on the water.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, look what we got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you brought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well at least we won't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you still cold?  Do you want to go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I'm beginning to think you might be right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think this may be the place for us after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am sorry Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.  If we're very quiet the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And nobody knows we're here except for Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well it must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're fine right?  Aren't we?  Whatever happens darling.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, it was, it's bound to come out sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello?  Hello?  What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What are we to do if they suddenly walk in on us?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With the most perfect poise?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Certainly.  And I shall probably do a court courtesy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: um- Things that should matter dreadfully don't seem to matter at all when one's happy do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is so horrible is that one cannot stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, darling.  Don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true.  I mean, the whole business it's a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mean that, that sacred and beautiful thing love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  I mean just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that all mean?  That's what I asked myself on my quest for ultimate truth.  What does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Oh, darling.  You mustn't be serious, that's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable.  Laugh at them.  Be flippant.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Laugh at all their sacred shibboleths.  Flippancy brings the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So if I'm to laugh at everything then I must laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, certainly, you must.  We're figures of fun alright.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long will it last?  This ludicrous overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  That fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, dear, shall we want that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, it depends on how well we've played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What happens if one of us dies?  I mean, does the other one still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, yes, yes, with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's serious enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  No it isn't.  That's very laughable, a cunning little mystery all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, and who isn't talking nonsense?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers hmmm?  Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and party as much as we can like quite idiotic school children.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's savor the delight of the moment.  Come kiss me darling before worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliot, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do, you see?  As long, no I don't care what you do, see?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can put green paint all over your body and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you dear.  The same applies to you...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...only if you ever so much as look at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought a little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Charles, that was his name, Charles.  Oh, God he was so wiggled so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible little thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know you did.  You threw it out the window and into the Grand Canal.  I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that rile last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, the worst one was in Cannes when you-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I burnt a hole in my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you're curling iron burnt a hole in my dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Yeah.  That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and saw us rolling on the floor, scratching and biting like panthers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will never forget his face. Ooh-rah [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How ridiculous.  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And much sillier too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The real cause of that rile was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey sweetie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's it- going?  Oh I'm so tired.  Oh, I just woke up. Mmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh, -Um

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why the sad face?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: they need me out there sooner than I thought

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where?  Who?  What are you talking about?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They want to deploy me next week.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Next week?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Overseas?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For how long this time?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They said anywhere from two to three years.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  What do you mean two to three years?  Don't they know that you have a wife and an expectant child?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I told them that but they--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: --need me on the specialist honey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't.  We need you.  I need you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to go but,-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care about the money.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: but they said they'd increase my pay by triple-there promotion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you're leaving next week so you won't even be here for Anna's birth?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do this whole thing by myself?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey you're not going to be by yourself--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll have internet set up, we'll get web cameras and everything.  My whole family's here too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Carry her for nine months and then yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not the same thing.  It's not like having you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't do this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can do it.  Alright?  You can, you can be strong, you can be strong for both of us alright?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sick of being strong-- --for us.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know what to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to - I don't- I don't want to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can say no?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I can't say no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You could.  You really could.  You could-- --get into another line of work.  I could start working after Anna's born?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The last guy who said no was fired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I put in fifteen years in this job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm so close.  Five more years and I retire-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and we'll have that happy life.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Happiness for me is having you here with me

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and watch our child grow, see her take her first steps, her first words.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey after a year I can be back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You said two years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They want me there two years but I could probably get

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: maybe get some vacation-- --once it quiets down there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A whole year? --We're not talking about like a couple months here.  I mean this is a whole year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I know.  But they really need some good guys there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What could happen in a year?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And this isn't the first time you know?  I mean you always...sending you off to different places and...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well that's the kind of work I'm in honey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know if that's how I want to live my life.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just going to be--it's going to go faster than you think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Joe I'm serious I don't want to have to have a little girl to tell...asking every day where's daddy, where's daddy and have to tell her that he's away--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: far away and he won't be here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You tell her-- [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm done.  I can't honey.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's over.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey I can't do it anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?  No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need you here.  Anna needs you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So I have--you want me to choose between you guys or my career?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I going to do?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Priorities honey, priorities.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want to--what am I going to do if I leave this job?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're smart.  You could go back to school--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: finish your Master's that you were started never finished.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Fine.  I'll see if I can talk to them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, Brian, if they uh--it's been three years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, you just got to keep on going.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I don't know, I--maybe this isn't for me. You know, maybe this isn't the right business for me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I see all these other people getting commercials and work and it's like I'm not getting anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have no money behind me. Nothing. I'm twenty five and--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Russel Crowe wasn't forty until he got his big stuff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If you really want to do it-I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I'll have to wait twenty five years-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you got to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -just going and auditioning and auditioning and rejection after refection, it's like--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You could. You could. We just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: we're just pooling our funds together.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, I just don't know if I can handle it. I mean, you're helping me so much financially it's like I can't survive on my own without you. I don't like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't owe me anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm not doing anything. Like I'm not giving anything into this world.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You are, you're going to class, you're learning, you're getting better. When you finally get that role you're going to be prepared.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but what if I never make it? What if I studied all my life, this theatre, this acting, and I'm never going to get anywhere. I'm never going to be able to have a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God, Anna, you're still young. Don't even think about that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Time is passing by. Every year it's

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: a part left than I can do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're only twenty five, okay? Some people don't start until they're thirty five.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, I just [BREATHING] I get frustrated

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What would you do- What would you do if you didn't? You can go to law school.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the thing. I don't know. I don't know anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Law school? Maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know. I don't know anything other than this, though, is the problem. This is my life. This is what I built everything about, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See? So you can't just quit now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, I could go to law school, but I'm just not passionate about it, you know? Like I'm not--it doesn't drive me, it doesn't motivate me. I--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Have you been going to auditions and stuff?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I mean, I get a call-back and stuff, but-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I need a break. I need something to break me out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How's the job? Still waiting tables at Denny's?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Unfortunately.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, so I go to--get an education for four years and I'm waiting tables at Denny's.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, they tip well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Brian-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's not funny. I just don't know what I'm going to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe you could start teaching. I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I guess I could.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Go back to school. You know? Another three more years, get your master's.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Close to thirty. Oof, it's going to be tough.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my God, look at that. Huh-oh, how many carats is that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. [LAUGHTER]. Dude, I don't know. It's- Probably. It's huge. I don't even know how to like wear it. My hand is like going down like really low. I can't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like eighteen? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I- Yeah, it's-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So how did he do it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, man. So I was--okay, so we went to go see this show on Broadway, right? And it was The wed- the wed- The Lousy Chaperone. Have you seen that one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, The Lousy Chaperone. [LAUGHTER] Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right. Right. Right. So, and there's like a whole like wedding scene in it. All right, not the--Drowsy, Drowsy [LAUGHTER] --not the Lousy. [LAUGHTER]. Um - So Drowsy. So I go to see this Drowsy Chaperone. And uh-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Uh- Drowsy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: at the end of the performance, you know, like we're all clapping and stuff. And all of a sudden I look over and

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Joe's gone. -where did he go, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh. Oh-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I'm like oh, he went to the- -the bathroom, but he didn't tell me, I didn't even notice him leaving. And all of a sudden, I swear to God, I'm sitting there and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he comes up onstage-- And the entire cast everyone just like

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: oh-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: goes up there and everyone's clapping and he's standing there and they put a spotlight on him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I'm like freaking out. I'm like what the hell's going on, you know. I don't know what's going on. And so he's like standing there and then all of a sudden they give him a microphone-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and he just starts doing like this little spiel about me and like

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he asked me to marry him, like- onstage. I was like, I couldn't believe--and I had to walk up there and I was, like I think I tripped or something.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wha- What'd you say? You said yes, right? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I said yes, but I, yeah, I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know- it just like took me, took me by surprise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He scored points.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you get a standing ovation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah. Everyone--yeah. And people--friends of ours were in the audience, I didn't know about, like family members.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. It was great.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you serious?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was--I cried,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you deserve to cry. I mean, tears of happiness.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like a loser, I cried.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, I don't know, I--it's so weird to think I'm marrying somebody 'cause I feel so young, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So where- where- where is this--have you talked about where it's going to be?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No plans. or any- and probably

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like I think I want to get married--I want to have two weddings. One here, then one in Europe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hawaii? No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. Hawaii's for honeymoons. But uh--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh. Like Paris? On the Eiffel Tower?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, maybe. I don't know. I've been there so many times. I think it's--we're going to get married in Spain and then we're going to get married here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He's rich enough. Maybe you can rent out the Eiffel Tower for your--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's awesome. [LAUGHTER] Marriage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I'm so excited. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.  It's a good thing.  You know, it's lovely here and the air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, not sorry, but I'm not going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You saw that and then you've been kind of--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so.  But they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would, your mother, anyway.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From her point of view, why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well wouldn't you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have no imagination.  That's all I know to tell you.  I'm embarrassing you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I wanted someplace we'd never been; someplace where we'd be brand new to each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is wrong, don't you; this yard, this chair?  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever?  You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  'Til then, you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, give me a kiss.  Give me a -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.  I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've waited to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit around and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it, Chris?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it, Chris?  Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what's wrong.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I suppose there has been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, gees.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a little time to toss that off because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time it'd been raining several days.  And this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks; put them in my pocket.  That's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I got this idea watching them go down, everything was being destroyed, see?  But, to me, it seemed there was one new thing that was made,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: a kind of responsibility.  Man for man.  You understand me?  And then I went home and it was incredible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them was some sort of bus accident.  Then I went to work for dad and that whole rat race again.  I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: because nobody was changed.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive;

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to open that bank book; to drive the new car; to see the new refrigerator.  I mean, you can take these things out of a war, but when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have to be a little better because of that.  Otherwise, we have is really loot and there's blood on it.  I don't want to take any of it.  I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way anymore, Chris.  Because you have a right to everything you have, everything, Chris; to me, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And your money, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  You should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie, I'm going to make you a fortune.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're leaving tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  They just called.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is really-this is unfair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't see [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know what to say.  I don't want to go but I don't have a lot of choice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean we both knew that this was going to happen.  It's just that I feel that, you know, I don't want Susie growing up without a mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And, uh, I'm afraid that if you, you know, when you leave, you won't come back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm going to come back.  I need you to believe that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need you to believe that too.  How am I supposed to believe everything's going to be okay if you don't?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll believe it, but- I'll believe it but it- I don't know that that's going to happen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you have to have faith because I don't have a choice and I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You do have a choice.  You don't have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think I want to leave you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have a choice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have to do this.  I don't want to leave.  Do you think I want to miss seeing her grow up?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It's just you don't have to do this for a living you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a smart person.  There are other things you can do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look we both knew what this meant when I signed on

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And now- and now it's really shitty timing but now I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean I'm the one who has to leave here.  I'm the one who has to leave the two of you.  At least you get to be together.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just not going to work out without you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean we can't-we're not a complete family without you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'll come back.  What is that supposed to mean?  You're not willing to wait for me to come back?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course I'm going to wait.  I just- I just don't like the idea of this happening because this isn't the last time this is going to happen. You're going to go on more tours and stuff.  I just- I can't-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't deal with this emotionally.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you to leave.  I want you to leave the service.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I can't very well do it today.  I still have to leave tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can do it today.  You don't have to do anything.  You don't have to do anything you don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're not making this any easier for me, you know.  I'm the one who has to go and you're really not helping.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look I'm just telling you that you don't have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I do have to go. And I need to know that you're here waiting for me and that you believe that I'm coming back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's all I'm saying... No you don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks that helps.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just really unfair.  This is- this is bullshit.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel much better now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're acting like, you know, you're the one who's going all through, you know, all this shit and it's really- it's really not.
