dialogue.text: What web- I didn't go to a website - why would I need to - it's the D.M.V.. You come to the D.M.V., you wait in line for three hours, and then you go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, maybe you should

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I waited in line now I'm ready to get my stuff and then go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right. So maybe you should go home now and get your paperwork and come back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir but there's a lot of people waiting. So if you won't move out of the way, then I'm going to have to call security.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, oh my-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir, it's not my choice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I was just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not. It is slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's so P.R. I mean, somebody's giving you a good bill about this wonderful event that's going to happen on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'm not the only one. Look at all these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Exactly. Everyone else is told the same thing. It keeps them feeling excited. Keeps them coming back. Keeps them thinking life's going to start at any minute now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. It's still fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something? Don't take this wrong, but are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, Goddamn it, don't ask me that. You always ask me that. Why do you ask me that? I hate it. It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, then what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, it's-we just-we're looking at this evening in a different way, both of us. We both have different ideas of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it, alright? We come down here, the grunion arrive, they do their little fish business, we go ooh, ah, look at the fish, and then they go home and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're not seeing the grunions?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, Augie, we've never seen them. They're never going to come.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We missed them twice. That's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is as many times as we've tried. That's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll see them this time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, we won't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's impossible. It's like waiting around. Waiting to see Santa Claus, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like I feel like my whole life I've been just standing on this beach with my hands clasped waiting for these fish to show up and these fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I did. I always do. But it's like every time I try nothing ever happens.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish. Nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God's sake, Augie, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been turning this thing over in my head trying to figure out when the point was when we took a turn for the worse, and I can't seem to pinpoint it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You were fine during the phone call from Marge. Dinner was okay. Doing the dishes was no problem. Let's see. I took a shower. You were watching the news. You said Augie, I think the grunion are running. I said great, let's go. I feel lucky tonight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And so I'm getting the animals, putting the animals out in the yard. I'm putting on my jacket, getting the car out of the garage-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the last time we came here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You brought a bottle of champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We took off our shoes and we danced barefoot in the sand. Under the moon.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you whispered so intimately in my ear so I could feel your words.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, that moment-that was it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I told myself finally, this is how happy I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute. I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dancing barefoot in the sand. Drinking out of a bottle of champagne.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, right? You said let's get some champagne, and I said time's-a-wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want this to be like the other time, right? That's it. Right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want to remember something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right. I got it. Of course. Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? What? Do you want me to breathe in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again? What? What? Do you want to get a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A new carpet? A poodle?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A-a back rub, some ice cream, a suicide pact. What the hell do you want, Carla?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want things to turn out the way that they're supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Jesus, welcome to the human race.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you think this is how I thought it was going to turn out? Do you think I had some great fantasy down the line? That four years down the line that we'd come to the beach and argue with each other over fish?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I was just like you. I thought it was going to be all peaches and roses and everything great. And the wind in our hair and the sand in our toes, and the fish will always come and the bills will pay themselves, and we'll have three big fat rosy kids. And oh God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what you get? The jokes on us, baby. Because do you know what you get? Huh? Carla? Do you know what you get? You get this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This what? What is this? This is nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's not. It's standing on the beach waiting and fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Things have never turned out anything the way that I thought they would be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know. Me neither.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, this is, this is everything, and it's a lot, but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's not something else. Do you know what I'm trying to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are, Augie, and I know you wanted this evening to be nice, but I can't help thinking of being somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, maybe if you were with someone else too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know. But I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, anything I do I'd rather be doing with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, don't you know that? I mean, you're the one that probably wants to be with somebody else. Somebody that didn't take herself so seriously, could enjoy herself more.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually now that you mention it, no, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess we're just in the wrong spart-spot with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Seemed like a pretty good spot to me. I mean, look at the view of the moon we've got from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I noticed that. It's beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can see right over the water.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look what we got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You brought refreshments?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At least we won't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you still cold? Do you want to go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I was thinking you might be right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe this is the right place after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If we're very quiet the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Wow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all going to miss him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmm hmm. I never knew it was going to be this hard, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird 'cause it's like you expected it to happen and eventually-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he had cancer, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm, Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They thought he got--would get better and he did, and then it just- things turned bad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turned around for the worst, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't know him, Tricia, but uh- I heard that he was a great man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was amazing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I loved that boy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We did everything together, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird, I think. I feel so alone, you know? What am I going to do now? Now that he's gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's so young. It seems so--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: so wrong in so many ways.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: His poor parents. You know, it's their only son.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Kind of a whole year. I mean, he suffered with this, this monster, this thing, this disease.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was in chemo the whole time, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he just got that baseball scholarship.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. He was, he had so much going for him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So handsome, so young, so gifted.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So talented.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Such a sweet person, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How's his parents doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can you imagine, though, you know, as a parent, just losing a kid? Twenty-two years old.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird, I kind of feel like part of me is gone now, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because this other half was just kind of like ripped away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You guys were pretty close, weren't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was like, he was like my brother, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was my brother.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just seems so unfair, is the way it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, he had that really pretty girlfriend for like about a year and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What was her name?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Kelly. Kelly Uveny.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kelly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They talked about getting married and--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Trying to have a baby.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. But then when he got cancer and it got bad, you know, she just took off and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: so I was there for him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Some people.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, but you were there all the hospital days. By his bed-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. God, I loved that kid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So nice, so positive.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We need more people like him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Joe, do you think he knew I loved him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I never told him, I love you, but-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I loved him so much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if Benny was smart like that- but-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sure he loved you too. He just didn't know it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, finally I got to the line, the front of the line. I've been waiting there for like half an hour.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] It's so hot in here. Hoo.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, um-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You didn't fill this out right. All right. It says that you have to fill out the back sheet of this, but you filled out the yellow sheet of it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no, no. The lady over there, she told me to fill out the front and she said to wait in this line.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know. Some lady. Sonya or something.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She- she probably doesn't even work here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me? No, no. I waited in the line over there..

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right  Uh-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and she told me to come over here and she said to fill out everything on the application and I did that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I-- No, no, no, I--you don't understand. I have to go back to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You just take--all right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you didn't fill this paper at work out right and it's going to take another fifteen minutes to do it and look at how long the line we got here so just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am not-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay, just go back and fill it out real quick and I'm sorry, you have to get back in line and wait. I can't let you cut.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But you don't understand. I cannot get back in line because I have to go back to work. I will get fired if I don't leave here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe you should have got here earlier than so you had a lot of time to do this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But I was at work and the lady told me to come and work it and to stand in the line.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know who this lady is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey.  How's it going?  I haven't seen you in awhile.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty good Susanna.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Guess who got into U.S.C.?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Me. Yeah, I did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No way. Are you serious? Oh my God.  Congratulations. I'm so excited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got into the...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got into cinema production.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  You didn't get into production.  There's no way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  It's like it's harder than getting into Harvard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  Oh my God.  Oh my God Joe I am so happy for you.  Well you know what that means?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're going to be here and I'm going to be in LA so we can be together now.  I mean we can be in the same city.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Holy shit...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can party.  We can have fun.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This will be like high school but even better.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Hopefully it won't be like high school.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh man I am so proud of you, that is...how did you get...I mean what did you do?  How did you find out or what...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I came home and my mom was like Joe uh-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have some bad news.  I was like what?  She's like not really you got into U.S.C. and I was like, I was like oh my God.  I was about to tear my own hair out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  This is so crazy.  I mean I didn't get into any other school but I got into the school I wanted.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you say yes yet?  I mean have you sent in your answer?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God the first minute I got it I sent it back in.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is so great, you know, because I gone fit on downtown so I'm going to be like right here.  I think I'm going to be living at City Lights downtown.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is so exciting.  This is like a new chapter in our lives.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, it really is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're doing what we want to do, then four years later we're going to be working professionals, making money, sipping martinis every day.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God hopefully.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Man I'm just so happy for you.  I just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm happy for you but I'm happy for me cause that means you're going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And tonight my parents want to take me out to sushi and they said I could bring you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh great. I would love to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah and they said get whatever you want and...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmmm some miso soup.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Some miso soup.  You can get whatever.  You can get a vat full of miso soup.  God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ah man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is going to be so great.  I have so many great ideas.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Did you...I mean do send in like how long after you send in your application did you hear?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to start off.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It took them, oh man, it took them like, I mean what it's like April now and any letters that come in April are usually the rejection letters so I was just like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were like...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was struck.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my God.  I am so proud of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, nobody knows we're here except for Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are we to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right, aren't we darling? Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello? What? Ugh, wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] God, it sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: things that should matter dreadfully don't seem to matter at all when one's happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um terrible thing is one can't stay happy. Well, it's true. I mean, the whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mean that sacred and beautiful thing, love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean? That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth. What does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me. I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. You mustn't be serious, my dear one, that's what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable. Laugh at them. Be flippant. Laugh at all the sacred shibboleths. Flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if I laugh at everything I'm going to have to laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh, certainly you must. We're figures of fun, all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So how long is it going to last? This ludicrous, overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. The fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, well, shall we want that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we play it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what if happens if one of us is to die? Does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. Yes, he must with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's serious enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No, it isn't. Death's very laughable. A cunning little mystery. All done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run. Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's blow strumpets, blow-blow trumpets and squeakers and party as much as we can like small quite idiotic school children. Let's savor the delight of the moment. Come, kiss me darling, before worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do, see? As long-you can paint yourself bright green all over and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you, dear. The same applies to you. Except that if I ever so much as catch you looking at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles. That was his name. Charles. He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible little thing. I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did. You threw it out the window and into the Grand Canal. I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your-your curling iron burnt a hole in my dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I burnt a hole in my comb too, and all the towels in the bathroom. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah. And that was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling on the floor and biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. Oh man. Couldn't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I will never forget his face. Ooh-rah [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.
